conversation:
Shadowheart: You should leave it. Or even destroy it, if possible.
Player: Don't be ridiculous - there could be something useful here.
Shadowheart: This rubbish is an offering to Selûne. At best, it's worthless. At worst... who knows? Could be cursed.
Shadowheart: Do not trifle with that moon witch or her trinkets. Only trouble will follow.
Player: Why do you care so much?
: False
Shadowheart: Because we've enough troubles and burdens as it is. Common sense, that's all.

Shadowheart: I should've just stayed quiet. You want the truth? Fine.
Shadowheart: I worship Shar, Mistress of the Night - Selûne's twin and foe.
Shadowheart: Now that you have the truth, please don't make a big fuss about it.
Wyll: A Shar worshipper? Not my usual quarry - nor my usual ally.
Player: You could have told me. How long were you going to keep this secret?
Shadowheart: Forever, ideally. And you assume too much about what I can and cannot tell.
Shadowheart: Secrecy is everything for Shar's children. It's our code, our creed, our shield.
Shadowheart: I even keep secrets from myself - I had my memories suppressed, so that nothing I knew could be used against the Dark Lady. Once I prove myself, my memories will be restored.
Shadowheart: I'm not sorry I kept this from you. Not one bit.
Shadowheart: Though perhaps that might change, if you can show an open mind.
Player: I can't trust you. Best if we travel separately for now.

GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: Hello, sweetness.
Player: What happened to Mayrina? Did you do something to her?
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: I don't like busybodies.
Player: Do you treat all your guests so poorly?
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: Hm?
NodeContext: You're shocked the player corrected you. Your expression should be neutral, tense moment as we're not sure how you'll react
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: You're quite right, petal.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: Forgive me if I get a bit sharp. My work wears something awful on me.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: You see, I help people from all over Faerûn.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: And you, petal - well, you need a lot of help.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: That wriggler swimming in your brain juice is a bit of an inconvenience, isn't it?
Player: Something isn't right. That woman - why is she with you?
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: Busybodies are not appreciated around here.
Gale: She's a pregnant lady in distress. We can't just stand by and pretend she's not here.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: I'll talk about your wriggler - and that's it. Last warning.
Player: Fine. Can you remove the parasite?
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: Quicker than you can say 'Yes, Auntie.'
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: What do you say? Want me to take care of the little bugger?
Player: Such things are rarely done for free. What's the real bargain here?
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: You're a sharp one. I am proposing a deal, but it's different from your little pact. You see, I prefer personal things.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: One of your pretty little peepers.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: I'll pluck it from your head, kiss it for luck, then back in it goes. Won't take but a moment.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: That is my price. Nothing more, nothing less.
Player: You have a deal.

Shadowheart: Wait... you're the one who left me to die on the ship.
NodeContext: Recognition. Narrows her eyes accusingly. This isn't just some random potential threat approaching, but someone who abandoned her in a life or death situation,
Narrator: *Suddenly you see what she sees. Feel what she feels. Anger. Bitterness. A will to survive.*
Shadowheart: ...Agh! Did you feel that? You've got the same thing - in your head...
Player: Did you miss the part where we were hurtling through the Hells? I had to save myself.
Shadowheart: Excuses. You didn't even try. You just ran.
Lae'zel: As if you would have done differently.
Shadowheart: I'm not the coward here, flatface.
Shadowheart: No matter. We survived the Hells, survived the crash.
Shadowheart: But we mightn't survive these things in our heads. They're going to consume us from the inside and turn us into mind flayers.
Player: You know about mind flayers? Tell me everything.
Shadowheart: I don't know much, but enough to be afraid. This is how they breed. We host their spawn, and once they're ready, they'll tear right through us.
Shadowheart: I'm not sure how much time we have left, but I'm not going to wait to find out.
Shadowheart: You and I need a healer.
Shadowheart: Finding one won't be easy in this wilderness. We'll need supplies.
Shadowheart: I was hoping to search through this door for something of use...
Shadowheart: But it looks like you've beaten me to it.
Shadowheart: Hopefully there's no more of these creatures along the way.
Player: Do you know if anyone else survived the crash? There were lots of people in those pods.
Shadowheart: No, unless you count these monsters.
Shadowheart: You're the friendliest face so far.
Player: Do you know if anyone else survived the crash? There were lots of people in those pods.
Shadowheart: No, unless you count these monsters.
Shadowheart: You're the friendliest face so far.
Player: Do you know if anyone else survived the crash? There were lots of people in those pods.
Shadowheart: No, unless you count these monsters.
Shadowheart: You're the friendliest face so far.
Player: Alliances have been made on less. I could use your help.
Shadowheart: I might've considered it... but your choice of company so far leaves a great deal to be desired.
Shadowheart: Get rid of the gith. Then we can talk about helping each other.
Lae'zel: I offer you cleansing. You'd cast it aside for this shka'keth?
Player: I'm not going to just abandon my companion on a whim.
Lae'zel: Your loyalty is noted but not commended.
Shadowheart: Fine, put your faith in a marauding freak. Just do it away from me.
Shadowheart: She'll turn on you. You'll see.
Player: Leave.
Shadowheart: Go on, then. Just don't be surprised when your friend turns on you.

Shadowheart: Finally, some good fortune. Come morning, we know what to do.
Shadowheart: I can't wait to get this thing out of my head.

Shadowheart: It took me so long to find you.
Player: You're infected, same as me. How did you get here?
Shadowheart: Quiet! I can't... concentrate with all these voices! Just listen.
Shadowheart: The whispering won't let me sleep. It keeps pushing me - to you.
Shadowheart: Even when I'm awake, I dream. There's blood, there's so much blood.
Shadowheart: I can't sleep. The whispering won't let me. It keeps pushing me - to you.
NodeContext: On, " to you" SH's hand drifts toward a knife tucked into her belt at the small her back
Wyll: Whispering? Her brain's been bugged too.
: True
Narrator: *There is a knife hidden in her belt. Her fingers twitch towards the hilt, ready to draw the blade.*
Player: Keep your hands away from that blade.
Shadowheart: I keep thinking about the knife going deep. It's the only thing they want me to see.
Shadowheart: And I think they'll stop once I deal with you.
Player: You can't kill me just because some 'whispers' told you to.
Shadowheart: I can't see anything else! I can't shake it.
Shadowheart: The whispering's already quieter here. Once you're dead, it'll be gone entirely.
Player: You're exhausted - not thinking straight. You need to rest.
: True
Shadowheart: Rest where? I can't leave. The whispers won't let me leave.
Player: Attack her.

Shadowheart: All right. As I said, Shar is my patron, my mistress. Goddess of darkness and loss.
Shadowheart: I assume you've heard of her?
Player: She doesn't sound very appealing, going by her titles.
Shadowheart: The night brings comfort. Through loss, we find acceptance. In the arms of the Dark Mother we find peace.
Player: I don't quite understand.
Shadowheart: Most fear the dark, like children, because in darkness they see their fears reflected.
Shadowheart: But Shar teaches us to step beyond fear. Beyond loss. In darkness we do not hide - we act.
Shadowheart: Pain. Hope. The promise of better days. All of these are heavy cloaks that bend our backs and burden our hearts.
Shadowheart: We shed those cloaks. Before Shar we stand gloriously naked, beyond the vanities of mortals.
Player: When you put it like that, it seems strangely comforting.
Shadowheart: There's comfort, yes. But often there has to be pain beforehand...
Shadowheart: We tear down the lies the world is drunk on: the institutions they trust, the so-called gods they worship. The lives they cling to.
Shadowheart: We destroy false idols, topple corrupt organisations, fight heretics wherever they're found.
Shadowheart: There's often suffering - death even. Many people break before they embrace Shar's truths.

Shadowheart: Wait. It's you... you're the one who tried to free me, on the ship.
NodeContext: Recognition. She lowers her guard as she realises the player's not an immediate threat - in fact, they'd tried to help her in a life or death situation previously.
Shadowheart: At least you made the effort.
Narrator: *Suddenly you see what she sees. Feel what she feels. Confusion. Resolve. And a hint of gratitude.*
Shadowheart: ... agh! Did you feel that? You've got the same thing I do - in your head.
Shadowheart: ... agh!  You - you've got the same thing I do, in your head. I felt it.
Player: I didn't feel a thing. No idea what you're talking about.
Shadowheart: Come on. The chase through Hell? The creatures? What they did to us? The tadpoles?
Shadowheart: These things are going to consume us from the inside and turn us into mind flayers.
Player: You know about mind flayers? Tell me everything.
Shadowheart: I don't know much, but enough to be afraid. This is how they breed. We host their spawn, and once they're ready, they'll tear right through us.
Shadowheart: I'm not sure how much time we have left, but I'm not going to wait to find out.
Shadowheart: You and I need a healer.
Shadowheart: Finding one won't be easy in this wilderness. We'll need supplies.
Shadowheart: I was hoping to search through this door for something of use...
Shadowheart: But it looks like you've beaten me to it.
Shadowheart: Hopefully there's no more of these creatures along the way.
Player: It'd be nice to have another hand in the fight.

Shadowheart: Get rid of the gith. Then we can talk about helping each other.

Shadowheart: I'm not sorry I kept this from you. Not one bit.

Viconia DeVir: This 'Absolute' is but an upstart; disturbing the natural order and threatening to impede the glorious return of Lady Shar's pure, endless darkness.
Viconia DeVir: I had to act. I had to strangle that foul conspiracy while it was still in the cradle.

Player: Can't you kill the one inside yourself? I thought 'gods' were all-powerful.
Vlaakith: Perhaps I misheard. You would not speak ill of a god. Would you?
Player: I spoke too hastily - please forgive me.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player enters the camp, Wyll waiting at a side, fully in view. A diabolical circle draws itself onto the ground in front of you and Wyll, shocked/surprise, and Mizora in devil form rises from it, maybe can have a turn and a noble pose at the end.
Mizora: Sorores surge. Testis esto pacti mei.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Two more diabolical circles form, and a female devil rises from each.
Mizora: Come, Sisters, be my testament. Notum sit in Baator.
Arbiter Cirrus: Notum sit in Baator.
: True
Narrator: *You've heard of such devils - Sisters of Justice, adjudicators of diabolical contracts and bargains.*
Wyll: Holy hells.
Player: Please, introduce me to your friends.
Mizora: Feena, Cirrus. Arbiters for the Hells, exemplars of justice.
Mizora: I come to bargain. The Hells demand witness.
Mizora: Your father is dead, Wyll. The Dead Three have claimed their prize.
Wyll: Dead? Godsdamn wretches!
Mizora: Still yourself, pup. Not every death is forever.
Mizora: Sisters.
Arbiter Cirrus: Infernus contractus te vocamus. Infernus contractus te vocamus. Infernus contractus te vocamus.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: A contract appears in the air, glowing. It is Wyll's contract.
Mizora: Your contract, Wyll. Signed in blood, forged in fire, bound in bone - but not unbreakable.
Player: Remain silent.
Mizora: Yet no contract is ended without sacrifice, Wyll. The cost must be paid.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Flames ignite Mizora and her two companions. Mizora's voice echos outward as if amplified by the Hells themselves.
Mizora: Wyll Ravengard. A choice is before you.
Mizora: Option one. I show you the way to your father. I guarantee him no harm except that from you and your allies. And you pledge your soul to me and the archdevil Zariel in a pact eternal.
Mizora: Option two. I break your pact. You are freed from your duty but retain your devil form. Your father dies by his enemy's hand.
Mizora: Name your sacrifice.
Karlach: Bloody Zariel. I won't let her take Wyll!
Wyll: Mizora, you arsehole.
Mizora: Choose.
Player: Let your father die. When the city's free, you can take his place.

Alfira: You're all right! Thank goodness, I was worried they'd got you too.
NodeContext: Relieved. Trying to be cheerful but you're upset, and just holding it together.
Player: Of course I am. As if there was any doubt.
Alfira: I'm afraid doubt is all I know these days.
Alfira: I still can't believe it. The cultists. The screams...
Alfira: Rolan, of all people, saved us.
Alfira: He said he stayed in the grove because of you, and I'm damn glad of it. Without him... well, none of us would be here.
Player: I know - Rolan isn't happy with me.
Alfira: Can you blame him? His brother and sister are gone. He's... dealing with it as best he can. We all are.
Alfira: How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: 'When the night is dark, stars shine brightest.' So keep on shining. It's going to be all right.
Alfira: 'Heart's Requiem', right? The hero survives a war and rebuilds her life - stronger than ever. A tale worth remembering - especially now.
Alfira: You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there.
Alfira: If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: I imagine the cultists are torturing them right now.

He Who Was: The air stirs in trepidation - you have the ledger.
Player: Here - take it.
He Who Was: We have it - her lies, her guilt. Madeline reported her friends to a Dark Justiciar and fled when they were butchered.
He Who Was: Well, she flees no more. I will be the conduit for Madeline's spirit. I will force her to face trial.
He Who Was: And you will be the judge. Make her beg, make her suffer.
Player: I'd like to hear her story first - I imagine it's quite the tale.
He Who Was: Careful - for a serpent in life is a serpent in death.
He Who Was: Witness her.
NodeContext: low, excited voice. Eyes roll back in his head as he looks up - body jerking. Falls to his knees.
Madeline: You! He said I was gonna be punished, that you'd be the judge. But I didn't mean to hurt anyone!
Player: You 'didn't mean' to kill your friends? How laughable.
Karlach: Pot, meet kettle.
Madeline: I said it didn't mean nothin', that Ben n' Marc were just drunk n' whining.
Madeline: The Dark Justiciar promised she was gonna chat with 'em. She promised.
Player: Don't blame others for what you did.
Madeline: You didn't see it. Didn't see what the Dark Justiciar did.
Madeline: She gave 'em a dagger each, and told 'em to press it against their stomachs.
Madeline: On the count of three, to 'start stabbin', and not to stop 'til she said so.
Madeline: She never said stop. I'd do anything to take it back. Anything.
Player: Yours is a classic tale of cowardice. Were you a character in a tale of mine, I would kill you off - immediately.
Player: You had the means to stop it - you chose not to. You let fear and cowardice rule you.

conversation:
Oskar Fevras: Gods above - I said buy me. If you didn't have the coin, you might have just said.
NodeContext: Taking in a scene of carnage - he asked us to bribe his captors and instead we slaughtered them. Distaste at our methods
Oskar Fevras: In any case, I am a slave no longer - and your money troubles are over, rest assured. For you have saved none other than Oskar Fevras.
Oskar Fevras: Well, you should at least know what you've paid for. I am the Oskar Fevras, at your service.
Player: What will you do with your freedom?
Oskar Fevras: Oh - run crying back to my patron I expect. My betrothed, I should say.
Oskar Fevras: A genuine pleasure. I'm in your debt - as is my patron. My betrothed, I should say.
Oskar Fevras: Assuming Lady Jannath still wishes to marry after our little... falling out.
: False
Oskar Fevras: Assuming Lady Jannath still wishes to marry after our little... falling out.
Player: What happened?
Oskar Fevras: She offered me a future, and so in a fit of madness I told her of my past.
Oskar Fevras: Of the woman I'd loved before she found me. Love still, in truth. She was... less than pleased.
Oskar Fevras: I made a timely retreat into the countryside. To paint, and clear my head. To choose, I suppose.
Player: I must know how this tragic tale ends. What option did you choose?
Oskar Fevras: Hm? Oh, absolutely none. Fame and wealth suit me very well, no doubt.
Oskar Fevras: And yet I think of that first love, and... I hesitate. Likely I'm going mad.
Oskar Fevras: Regardless! We have more immediate concerns - your reward once I've returned to the city, for one.
Oskar Fevras: Say - I don't suppose you could spare some coin, could you? Ease the discomforts of the road some?

Mizora: Option two. I break your pact, and you are freed from your duty. Your father remains dead, and Baldur's Gate loses its greatest champion.

Wyll: Mizora, you arsehole.
Mizora: Choose.

Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now.
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. Your kind have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: Most on this plane believe you to be innately cruel, violent beings. Evil, if you will.
Havkelaag: As citizens of the Underdark, we face similar stigmas. Totally unfounded, of course - our natures are as unfixed as any who walk the surface.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: You're letting your personal biases affect your method. Why assume they're evil?
Havkelaag: I assume nothing. Innate githyanki cruelty is an established fact - no doubt you witnessed it yourself in the retrieval of the egg itself.
Havkelaag: When I have a suitable sample for my study, I will, however, prove that the effects of their biological inclination are reversible.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: That kind of indoctrination and time-forced nurture violates the natural order. It invalidates the whole experiment.
Havkelaag: I won't bother to argue with you. An arboreal shaman can't be expected to understand the rigorous protocols of theoretical research.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: And what if your experiment fails?
Havkelaag: If the child remains evil after the experiment is concluded, it will be destroyed. Such is the fate of all used specimens.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: Sell the egg.
Havkelaag: Ah. Unfortunately, it seems I've mislaid my purse.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you'd consider simply donating it to the Society instead?
Player: Fine. Here you go.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows what’s inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn.
Halsin: But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do...
Halsin: How is this possible...?
Player: I escaped from an illithid ship after being infected. Maybe the process was interrupted.
Halsin: Perhaps... but I wouldn't want to place all my faith in blind luck.
Halsin: You weren't speaking lightly when you said you needed help. Let me tell you what I know.
Halsin: I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them.
Halsin: Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected.
Halsin: I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help.
Halsin: I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from.
Halsin: That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: Tell me what you've learned about the tadpoles' origins.
Halsin: I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers.
Halsin: Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic.
Halsin: If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: You seem to know a lot about this. Will you come with me to Moonrise?
Halsin: I wish I could, but there's still work I've yet to finish - blood I've yet to spill.
Halsin: I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise.
Halsin: I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: Kagha is dead. She was swayed by Shadow Druids. I had no choice.
Halsin: Kagha... This is my fault - I was her teacher. I will mourn her when I can.
Halsin: But there are other matters to attend to before that.
Halsin: Chaos is welcome, in doses; it helps keep balance. But this is too much - this is unnatural.
Halsin: It's too late to merely kill this horde's leadership - their forces are already marching. If you want me to help, you need to help me first.
Halsin: You must get ahead of them, muster the defences.
Player: The grove isn't my problem. I have to concentrate on saving myself.

Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I met an expeditioner claiming to work for you. She sought a githyanki egg.
Havkelaag: Yes, dear Lady Esther. One of our most reliable contractors, though unfortunately this particular request was too much even for her.
Havkelaag: I believe she quite lost her senses over the task. She came here insisting I purchase an owlbear egg from her, of all things.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you've stumbled across any githyanki eggs during your travels? The Society will compensate you for any we purchase, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You yourself have no doubt experienced the prejudice of those who assume that, as beings of the Underdark, we are inherently evil.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: What does this 'intellectually stimulating' upbringing look like?
Havkelaag: In the literal sense, I will need to induce the egg to hatch via the application of certain currents to the creature inside.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: Why follow the dogma of a draconic god?
Havkelaag: In my years of study, they're the closest I've found to moral perfection. Only under such rigorous 'goodness' will the subject stand a chance of being cured.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: No benefit could justify you inflicting such cruelty.
Havkelaag: Rigorous experimental methods demand we do not indulge our own emotional responses in the application of discomfort to our subjects.
Havkelaag: Only by the full, uninhibited application of psionic stimuli will we have a true measure of whether the child's innate evil has been cured.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: Sell the egg.
Havkelaag: Ah. Unfortunately, it seems I've mislaid my purse.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you'd consider simply donating it to the Society instead?
Player: Fine. Here you go.

Karlach: Holy fucking hells.
Wyll: Interesting. I don't recall sending out invitations to the Sisters of Justice.
Mizora: You do not call upon the Sisters. They come when the Hells demand witness.
Mizora: I come to bargain. The Hells demand witness.
Mizora: Your father is dead, Wyll. The Dead Three have claimed their prize.

Mizora: I had no hand in your father's death, Wyll. But that doesn't mean he might not still live.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: A contract appears in the air, glowing. It is Wyll's contract.
Wyll: Remain silent.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Flames ignite Mizora and her two companions. Mizora's voice echos outward as if amplified by the Hells themselves.
Mizora: Option one. I raise your father from the dead. And you pledge your soul to me and the archdevil Zariel in a pact eternal.
Mizora: Option two. I break your pact, and you are freed from your duty. Your father remains dead, and Baldur's Gate loses its greatest champion.
Mizora: Name your sacrifice.
Karlach: Bloody Zariel. I won't let her take Wyll!
Mizora: Silence, Karlach!
Wyll: Mizora, you arsehole.
Mizora: Choose.
Player: Leave him dead. When the city's free, you can take his place.

Viconia DeVir: Always a pleasure to see old acquaintances. But you would be wise to not interfere in this matter.
Player: Speak, then.
Viconia DeVir: Welcome to the true heart of the House of Grief. For what is grief but a facet of loss? And what is loss but the very nature of my Lady Shar's power?
Viconia DeVir: I saw in your mind, when we spoke above. Quite an adventure has brought you to this point - illithids, kidnapping, infection, the Hells, hunted by cultists and githyanki alike... and of course, the artefact.
Viconia DeVir: You have value. Quite an adventure has brought you to this point - illithids, kidnapping, infection, the Hells, hunted by cultists and githyanki alike... and of course, the artefact.
NodeContext: Ill-ih-thids
Player: I know I have value to my patron - but what you see in me I've no idea.
Viconia DeVir: Oh but I think you do - the Mapping unearthed much more than your heartform - I saw all your secrets.
Viconia DeVir: I felt Shadowheart's presence in your mind, and with it, the artefact. She succeeded in retrieving it, but then it is you who appeared, not her. Where is the artefact?
Player: The Astral Prism is with me. And it's staying with me.
Viconia DeVir: A bold claim given your current circumstances. I have not assembled my forces here just to spectate.
Viconia DeVir: Humour me with a little negotiation. Perhaps we can find terms that will allow blades to remain sheathed.
Player: All right, you wish to negotiate? Make me an offer then.
Viconia DeVir: How about the artefact for your life? And perhaps even my support in the battles yet to come, against the Absolute?
Player: The artefact alone can't save you. Best if we unite against our common enemy - the Absolute.
: True
Viconia DeVir: My interest is defeating the Absolute. It seems you're on that path already. I will not have it said that I am unreasonable.
Viconia DeVir: Shadowheart. Surrender her to me - she has much to answer for.
Player: Let me go, and I'll bring her to you.

Balthazar: Finally, we can talk face-to-face.
Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased.
Balthazar: I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Balthazar: But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Judging by how you're cowering in here, your survival?
Balthazar: I do not cower - I plan. I command. I create.
Balthazar: General Thorm trusts me. He knows I will deliver. He knows I will stand by him long after all others wilt and fall.
Balthazar: You, Z'rell, all the rest... you have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make.
Player: As you mention serving Ketheric, he sent you to find a relic, no?
Balthazar: General Thorm to you. But yes, recovering the relic is the crux of it. He commands, and I, his humble servant, fulfil that command.
Balthazar: While you, an infinitely more humble servant, fulfil my command. I will put you to work - as a scout.
Narrator: *This necromancer has Ketheric's trust. Helping him could be just what you need to gain access to the man himself.*
Player: A scout is little good if they don't know what to look for. What does this relic do?
Player: I need more to go on. Why is this relic so important? What does it do?
: False
Balthazar: Telling you will not make the task any less perilous. Just obey, and use your ignorance as a shield. You should be adept at that already.
Balthazar: The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: Sounds like you've good reason to be proud of the Nightsong - tell me more.
Balthazar: And spoil the surprise? I think not. But let's just say that the Nightsong was a unique specimen even before I began my work...
Balthazar: Words - even my words - are woefully insufficient. When you see for yourself, you will understand.
Player: What do you need me to do?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you.
Balthazar: The Nightsong is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes.
Balthazar: I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: For jobs like this it's good form to provide your operatives some extra resources.

Balthazar: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell...
Balthazar: ...and he will come.
Balthazar: My brother is no intellectual powerhouse, but he is strong, loyal and punctual. Should a fight turn against you, remember the bell.
Player: Keep it - this is your problem, not mine.
Balthazar: This is not a problem - it is an opportunity. And it is not a choice either - you will obey.
Player: Fine. I'll see what I can do.
Player: I'll see what I can do.

Karlach: Copper for your thoughts?
Karlach: Hey, soldier.
Player: Did you really think I wouldn't notice you here, devil?

Player: My sources say otherwise. Not a devil? Prove it.
Karlach: How should I do that exactly? Carve out my soul to serve with a nice side of turnips?
Karlach: If you'd just hear me out -

Narrator: *Her rage and desperation seep into you. She is a victim of the Blood War, not an agent of it.*
Karlach: Fuck. I'll never get used to that.
Karlach: Look, whatever else it may be, the tadpole isn't a liar. I never wanted to serve Zariel, and I escaped the first chance I could. So stand down.
NodeContext: Ready for a fight if needed.
Shadowheart: Let's take things down a notch, shall we? She's no devil, Wyll. You'll have to look elsewhere to find fodder for your blade.

Arabella: I don't see any - wait. Here they come!
Arabella: Sorry. Knocks the wind right out of me.
Player: I'd be more impressed if you'd actually killed it.
Arabella: I don't know how. I'd kill 'em all if I could. I - I just want my mum and pops.
Arabella: We followed Zevlor out here. Then he - he -
Arabella: Well. There was an ambush. Mum yelled 'run!' So we ran.
Arabella: I could hear 'em running behind me. 'Til I couldn't.
Arabella: Still can't find 'em - but I bet you can. You'll help me, I just know it!

GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Hail, friend. Fine day, isn't it?
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Forgive me - you're in no mood to talk about the weather. Your journey here was a hard one, no doubt.

GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Is this your first time in Baldur's Gate?
Player: It's best to not ask where I conduct my... business. For your own safety.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Is that so? Enigmatic soul, aren't you?
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: A word of advice then - you might not get as warm a welcome as in days gone by.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Used to be you'd arrive knowing you'd a full belly and a warm bed waiting for you. Not any more.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: These days, there's barely enough to go around. Add the refugees on top and... well, folk aren't feeling too generous.
Player: Sounds like that's your problem, not mine.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: If it were my problem, I'd do something about it. Instead they've stuck me guarding this door while they squabble over the donations.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Some well-to-do's in the city donated enough to see the newcomers right for the time being. Only they didn't bother helping everyone else.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Locals going without while strangers feast - it's stoked the fire, all right. Some Baldurians are kicking up a fuss round the front of the barn as we speak.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: If I wasn't wearing this uniform, I'd walk round there and teach them a lesson they'd never forget.
Player: The people of this city have grown selfish. They need reminding what true hardship is.
Nightwarden Minthara: We can be the reminder. Soft citizens make easy targets.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Too bloody right. They've gone soft behind those walls, forgotten what it's like to struggle, living hand-to-mouth.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: I say we march round there and slit a few bellies. Remind them how much worse things could be. What do you say?
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: We need to march round the front, and kill every last one of them. Let's see them eat our food with their guts on the floor. What do you say?
Player: Let's soak the earth with entrails, kill and kill again!

Balthazar: Ah, the interloper - and in one piece as well. Not an entirely unpromising specimen, for one naturally-born.

Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased.
Balthazar: I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.

Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Balthazar: But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Nere mentioned that you were seeking access to the Temple. Looks like you found it.

Player: It's simple - you need me. Don't pretend otherwise.
: True
Balthazar: ...Fine. Your usefulness may outweigh your insolence - for now. There are much grander things at stake.
NodeContext: A pause before 'fine' - weighing up the player's fate.
Balthazar: The Nightsong is my finest creation - if I never exceed myself, I will still die happy. Not that I ever intend to do something as gauche as truly dying, of course.
Balthazar: Now, given your prying nature, I have work for you, as a scout.
Balthazar: The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: Sounds like you've good reason to be proud of the Nightsong - tell me more.
Balthazar: And spoil the surprise? I think not. But let's just say that the Nightsong was a unique specimen even before I began my work...
Balthazar: Words - even my words - are woefully insufficient. When you see for yourself, you will understand.
Player: What do you need me to do?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you.
Balthazar: The Nightsong is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes.
Balthazar: I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: You have resources to spare - give me something to aid my search.

Balthazar: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell...
Balthazar: ...and he will come.
Balthazar: My brother is no intellectual powerhouse, but he is strong, loyal and punctual. Should a fight turn against you, remember the bell.
Player: Keep it - this is your problem, not mine.
Balthazar: This is not a problem - it is an opportunity. And it is not a choice either - you will obey.
Player: Fine. I'll see what I can do.
Player: I'll see what I can do.

Viconia DeVir: Always a pleasure to see old acquaintances. But you would be wise to not interfere in this matter.
Player: With such an audience? A trap, if I ever saw one.
Viconia DeVir: A trap? Perhaps. But not all traps need to be sprung. Sometimes it's wiser to await an even greater prey.
Viconia DeVir: I saw in your mind, when we spoke above. Quite an adventure has brought you to this point - illithids, kidnapping, infection, the Hells, hunted by cultists and githyanki alike... and of course, the artefact.
Viconia DeVir: You have value. Quite an adventure has brought you to this point - illithids, kidnapping, infection, the Hells, hunted by cultists and githyanki alike... and of course, the artefact.
NodeContext: Ill-ih-thids
Player: I don't know what you're talking about.
Viconia DeVir: Oh but I think you do - the Mapping unearthed much more than your heartform - I saw all your secrets.
Viconia DeVir: I felt Shadowheart's presence in your mind, and with it, the artefact. She succeeded in retrieving it, but then it is you who appeared, not her. Where is the artefact?
Player: Why do you even want it?
Viconia DeVir: I did not consent to questions. But I suppose you have undergone a great deal to reach this place, and anything I tell you cannot compromise me now - for you will either leave on my terms, or not at all...
Viconia DeVir: Whispers reached my ears from all corners - potential rivals of Lady Shar, all vying for the same prize. A new god, amassing the disaffected, the outcasts - those who should turn to us.
Viconia DeVir: This 'Absolute' is but an upstart; disturbing the natural order and threatening to impede the glorious return of Lady Shar's pure, endless darkness.
Viconia DeVir: I had to act. I had to strangle that foul conspiracy while it was still in the cradle.
Viconia DeVir: We learned all we could - the artefact was the one thing the Absolutists feared. The one thing they desperately wanted to keep out of their enemies' grasp. I had to have it.
Player: You thought you could best the Absolute? The githyanki?
Viconia DeVir: To fight so many foes openly could prove unwise. Shar's children are better deployed as daggers in the shadows, not massed upon a battlefield.
Viconia DeVir: So let the others fight, while we wait. Once they are spent and bloodied from each other, we would slip in and take the prize. Alas, most of those I sent, perished. All but one - Shadowheart.
Narrator: *Viconia trails off, holding your gaze with a dark, hungry look. She has staked everything on acquiring the Astral Prism.*
Viconia DeVir: I felt Shadowheart's presence in your mind, and with it, the artefact. She succeeded in retrieving it, but then it is you who appeared, not her. Where is the artefact?
Player: Say nothing.

Viconia DeVir: Humour me with a little negotiation. Perhaps we can find terms that will allow blades to remain sheathed.

Viconia DeVir: How about the artefact for your life? And perhaps even my support in the battles yet to come, against the Absolute?

Viconia DeVir: My interest is defeating the Absolute. It seems you're on that path already. I will not have it said that I am unreasonable.

Havkelaag: Ah, a surface dweller.
Havkelaag: You find yourself in the cradle of all knowledge relating to the Underdark: the Society of Brilliance.
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now.
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. Your kind have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: Most on this plane believe you to be innately cruel, violent beings. Evil, if you will.
Havkelaag: As citizens of the Underdark, we face similar stigmas. Totally unfounded, of course - our natures are as unfixed as any who walk the surface.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: You assume my people are evil, yet your research is built on sheer superstition.
Havkelaag: Enough of your kind have wreaked destruction on this plane for me to be confident in my assertion.
Havkelaag: When I have a suitable sample for my study, I will, however, prove that the effects of their biological inclination are reversible.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: You would teach the child virtue, but rear it without patience. Curious.
Havkelaag: Tell me, then, philosopher - if patience delays the fostering of the other virtues, can it be rightly called virtuous?
Player: Patience does not delay, it simply tempers virtue. Curtails it from excess.
Havkelaag: A cautious, hesitant instinct. One I am afraid we do not have time for.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.

Havkelaag: Rigorous experimental methods demand we do not indulge our own emotional responses in the application of discomfort to our subjects.
Havkelaag: Only by the full, uninhibited application of psionic stimuli will we have a true measure of whether the child's innate evil has been cured.

Havkelaag: Ah, a surface dweller.
Havkelaag: You find yourself in the cradle of all knowledge relating to the Underdark: the Society of Brilliance.
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I met an expeditioner claiming to work for you. She sought a githyanki egg.
Havkelaag: Yes, dear Lady Esther. One of our most reliable contractors, though unfortunately this particular request was too much even for her.
Havkelaag: I believe she quite lost her senses over the task. She came here insisting I purchase an owlbear egg from her, of all things.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you've stumbled across any githyanki eggs during your travels? The Society will compensate you for any we purchase, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])

Havkelaag: Most on this plane believe you to be innately cruel, violent beings. Evil, if you will.
Havkelaag: As citizens of the Underdark, we face similar stigmas. Totally unfounded, of course - our natures are as unfixed as any who walk the surface.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.

Havkelaag: When I have a suitable sample for my study, I will, however, prove that the effects of their biological inclination are reversible.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: You would teach the child virtue, but rear it without patience. Curious.
Havkelaag: Tell me, then, philosopher - if patience delays the fostering of the other virtues, can it be rightly called virtuous?
Player: Perhaps not. Patience is important, but cannot impede the other virtues.
Havkelaag: Then we are in accord - the time for action is now.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: An experiment like this will only confirm the surface dwellers' suspicion of us.
Havkelaag: Of course it won't. If anything, it will do quite the opposite. The academic institutions up here will finally be forced to take us seriously.

Havkelaag: I don't suppose you'd consider simply donating it to the Society instead?

GROUP_SteelWatchers: You are marked for special treatment. A defective Steel Watcher. Not simply an enemy of the people, but an enemy of the Absolute. Come quietly, or die.
GROUP_SteelWatchers: You are marked for special treatment. Not simply an enemy of the people, but an enemy of the Absolute. Come quietly, or die.

Wulbren Bongle: Good to see you. Wasn't sure you'd make it to the city. Regretting it yet?
Wulbren Bongle: I spent a lot of time thinking of worst case scenarios while I was locked in that cell you plucked me out of at Moonrise.
Wulbren Bongle: I didn't imagine anything as bad as this. The Gondians have handed Enver Gortash the means to bring about the end of liberty in Baldur's Gate.
Wulbren Bongle: And the citizens have rolled out the red carpet for their new tyrant.
Wulbren Bongle: Resistance fighters are few and far between - my Ironhands, what's left of the Harpers, and you. I hope.
Player: Gortash is a dead man - I have reasons of my own for taking him down.
Wulbren Bongle: As long as our objective is the same, the reason doesn't matter to me. We have a common enemy.
Wulbren Bongle: But neither of us gets what we want until we deal with our biggest obstacle.
Wulbren Bongle: The Steel Watch. They're a threat to you, me - and every man, woman and child in the city.
Wulbren Bongle: They act all civilised... servants of the people. But they only serve one man.
Wulbren Bongle: When he becomes Grand Duke, it will only get worse. Laws will change, freedoms will vanish, and soon you'll be accused and sentenced before you've even committed a crime.
Wulbren Bongle: And the fucking Gondians are to blame for all of it.
Player: Perhaps the Gondians were infected with a tadpole?

Wulbren Bongle: They invented the Steel Watchers. And they're building an army of them.
Wulbren Bongle: They've always been happy to provide their technology to despots in exchange for a stipend and the freedom to work in peace.
Wulbren Bongle: They would have licked Sarevok's boots given the chance, and now they'll kiss Gortash's ring while the city screams.
Wulbren Bongle: I had a plan to put a stop to them. But the way things are now, if we stick our heads above ground, the Watchers are on us like flies on shit.
Player: What was the plan?
Wulbren Bongle: Same as it always is. Eliminate the threat.
Wulbren Bongle: In this case - the foundry where these atrocities are produced.
Wulbren Bongle: The Gondians are ingenious. But we're more than equal to them - there's nothing they can build that the Ironhands can't tear down.
Wulbren Bongle: I've built something unique for just that purpose.
Wulbren Bongle: A runepowder bomb - first of its kind. Fifty wizards high on the Weave couldn't summon this kind of firepower.
Wulbren Bongle: Get the bomb inside the Gondian facility, and - boom. Problem solved.
Barcus Wroot: Wulbren, please. This is too far! Everyone in the foundry would be killed.

Wulbren Bongle: If they had any courage, they'd have refused him and died like heroes, spitting in his face.
Wulbren Bongle: Now they'll die like the dogs they are.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith looms in to face the player at their eye level.
Vlaakith: You bear that which is ours. But are you friend, or are you thief?
Player: Does it matter? I brought it back to you.
Vlaakith: That is no answer to my question.
Vlaakith: Hmm. HMMMMM.
NodeContext: Scary and torn while she considers you
Vlaakith: At least you brought it back. It is a start.
Vlaakith: We will test you. To assess whether you deserve reward or punishment.
Vlaakith: The Astral Prism - it is corrupted.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: I shall cleanse it for you, my queen. Tell me how.
InternalNodeContext: He's not altogether sure why this task is falling to the player and not to him, but also doesn't want to challenge his queen's motivations.
Vlaakith: SILENCE, W'wargaz.
Vlaakith: There is someone inside. Their mind is warped, broken - a blight.
Vlaakith: They are an agent of the Grand Design. Sent to sabotage the Astral Prism - our last defence against the return of the Illithid Empire.
Vlaakith: As long as they live, the Prism is compromised.
Vlaakith: Find the one inside and kill them. Be aware - they are not alone, and they will appeal to your trust. They are not to be believed.
Vlaakith: You must accept. Refuse, and know my fury.
Player: Can't you kill the one inside yourself? I thought 'gods' were all-powerful.
Vlaakith: Perhaps I misheard. You would not speak ill of a god. Would you?
Player: I spoke too hastily - please forgive me.

GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Hail, friend. Fine day, isn't it?
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Forgive me - you're in no mood to talk about the weather. Your journey here was a hard one, no doubt.

GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Is this your first time in Baldur's Gate?
Player: My past is none of your concern.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: No offence intended, just being friendly. You won't find many make others making the effort.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Used to be you'd arrive knowing you'd a full belly and a warm bed waiting for you. Not any more.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: These days, there's barely enough to go around. Add the refugees on top and... well, folk aren't feeling too generous.
Player: Is there anything I can do to ease these people's burden?
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: I've been asking myself the same question. I wouldn't be the first to interfere.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Some well-to-do's in the city donated enough to see the newcomers right for the time being. Only they didn't bother helping everyone else.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Locals going without while strangers feast - it's stoked the fire, all right. Some Baldurians are kicking up a fuss round the front of the barn as we speak.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: If I wasn't wearing this uniform, I'd walk round there and teach them a lesson they'd never forget.
Player: I'm all in favour of re-education. It sounds like they have a lot to learn.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: I knew you'd feel the same way.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: People here have gone soft living behind the city walls, forgotten what it's like live one day from destruction.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: I say we march round there and slit a few bellies. Remind them how much worse things could be. What do you say?
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: We need to march round the front, and kill every last one of them. Let's see them eat our food with their guts on the floor. What do you say?
Player: You're speaking my language. I'm in.

Balthazar: Finally, we can talk face-to-face.
Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased.
Balthazar: I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Balthazar: But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Nere mentioned that you were seeking access to the Temple. Looks like you found it.
Balthazar: Perhaps you'd be more useful dead than alive if you don't even know what I'm seeking here.
Balthazar: But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Enlighten me.
Player: Fine, consider your merits acknowledged. Care to enlighten me as to what's going on?
Balthazar: There is a relic here. One which General Thorm desires. No - needs. I will retrieve it for him...
Balthazar: ...and you will help me. Ignorant you may be, you've shown some prowess in scouting and combat by making it this far.
Balthazar: While you, an infinitely more humble servant, fulfil my command. I will put you to work - as a scout.
Narrator: *This necromancer has Ketheric's trust. Helping him could be just what you need to gain access to the man himself.*
Player: I need more to go on. Why is this relic so important? What does it do?
: False
Balthazar: Telling you will not make the task any less perilous. Just obey, and use your ignorance as a shield. You should be adept at that already.
Balthazar: The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: You need my help?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you.
Balthazar: The relic is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes.
Balthazar: I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: This sounds like your problem, not mine.
Player: Keep it - this is your problem, not mine.
Balthazar: This is not a problem - it is an opportunity. And it is not a choice either - you will obey.
Player: Fine. I'll see what I can do.
Player: I'll see what I can do.

Lord Enver Gortash: You have the Netherstones - they resonate with my own.
Lord Enver Gortash: I commend you for putting an end to Orin's madness - she must be screaming bloody murder in the Hells even now.
Lord Enver Gortash: How was the reunion? I trust you demonstrated your particular spark of creative genius?
Lord Enver Gortash: I always preferred your methods to hers. You have mastery over your Urges, Orin was consumed by her gruesome obsessions.
Player: You're wrong, my Urges are only ever a step away from controlling me.
Lord Enver Gortash: Bhaal allows you to pick your battles, as long as you do pick them. Orin thinks she needs to slash every throat in sight.
Lord Enver Gortash: My involvement with Orin was never a true alliance. A mad dog understands the yank of the leash and the hand of its master, but it cannot be an equal.
Lord Enver Gortash: You can be my equal.
Lord Enver Gortash: We will raise a Black Keep in Baldur's Gate. Then we will conquer the Sword Coast, and unite all its peoples under our rule. But first -
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The room shakes from a "brainquake".
Lord Enver Gortash: The brain awakens - we must act now.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Several Banites step from the corner shadows, one at a time. They look fierce and dangerous.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Finally, the Steel Watcher stepw forward. It activates, looking devastatingly powerful.
Lord Enver Gortash: Hand me the Netherstones, and we will rule as one.
Gale: Hmm. I can think of more trustworthy accomplices - more than a few, in fact.
Player: Take the Netherstones. We will control the brain and reform the Sword Coast in our image.

Shadowheart: There's something I want to talk to you about. Something important.
Shadowheart: Indeed. We're overdue for a talk... and a little honesty, on my part.
Player: Well now I'm intrigued. Do continue.
Shadowheart: I can never take for granted how someone might react when they learn I worship Lady Shar - easier to just keep it a secret than take the risk. But you showed you had an open mind.
Shadowheart: More than that, I even have an idol of the Nightsinger to call my own, thanks to you.
Shadowheart: I'm trying to say that you've earned my trust in a way very few ever have... I want that to mean something. I want you to know more about me - at least, from what I can remember.
Shadowheart: As long as I've prayed to Lady Shar, I've wished to serve her as a Dark Justiciar.
Shadowheart: There is scarcely a greater way to fully dedicate yourself to Lady Shar - save perhaps if you become the head of her church.
Shadowheart: Not my mother-mother, I should add. The Mother Superior. Head of Lady Shar's enclave in Baldur's Gate.
Shadowheart: Sometimes I wonder if she would ever deem me ready. I owe her everything, and I only wish to serve, yet she can prove... inscrutable.
Player: Well that was a load of nothing. I'm not sure why you bothered telling me that.

Karlach: Hey.
Karlach: Hey, soldier.
Player: Did you really think I wouldn't notice you here, devil?
Karlach: Well I'll be godsdamned - the Blade of Frontiers. Thought I'd shaken you for good. That'll teach me to underestimate you.
Karlach: Look - it's an honour to be chased by a famed hero. I'm no devil, though. Not by a long shot.
Player: I've hunted you to the Hells and beyond. It ends here, Karlach.
Karlach: For fuck's sake, you must be half troll to have a skull that thick.
Karlach: If you'd just hear me out -
Narrator: *A great fire roars through you - the fire of the First Hell.*
Narrator: *Her rage and desperation seep into you. She is a victim of the Blood War, not an agent of it.*
Karlach: Fuck. I'll never get used to that.
Karlach: Look, whatever else it may be, the tadpole isn't a liar. I never wanted to serve Zariel, and I escaped the first chance I could. So stand down.
NodeContext: Ready for a fight if needed.
Gale: Easy, Wyll. She's no devil. There's no fight to be had here.
Shadowheart: Let's take things down a notch, shall we? She's no devil, Wyll. You'll have to look elsewhere to find fodder for your blade.
Player: You don't know what this means. You don't know what you're asking me to do.
Karlach: I'm asking you to live, Wyll. I don't want to hurt you. And, to be frank, I'd rather not find out how the Blade got his name.
Karlach: I swear to you, on all I am, I'm not what you think.
Narrator: *Two souls hang in the balance. Kill Karlach, fulfil your contract - and condemn a possible innocent to the Hells. Or spare her and face the repercussions with Mizora.*
Player: I'm sorry, Karlach. There's too much at stake.

Wulbren Bongle: Good to see you. Wasn't sure you'd make it to the city. Regretting it yet?
Wulbren Bongle: I spent a lot of time thinking of worst case scenarios while I was locked in that cell you plucked me out of at Moonrise.
Wulbren Bongle: I didn't imagine anything as bad as this. The Gondians have handed Enver Gortash the means to bring about the end of liberty in Baldur's Gate.
Wulbren Bongle: And the citizens have rolled out the red carpet for their new tyrant.
Wulbren Bongle: Resistance fighters are few and far between - my Ironhands, what's left of the Harpers, and you. I hope.
Player: Gortash is a dead man - I have reasons of my own for taking him down.
Wulbren Bongle: As long as our objective is the same, the reason doesn't matter to me. We have a common enemy.
Wulbren Bongle: But neither of us gets what we want until we deal with our biggest obstacle.
Wulbren Bongle: The Steel Watch. They're a threat to you, me - and every man, woman and child in the city.
Wulbren Bongle: They act all civilised... servants of the people. But they only serve one man.
Wulbren Bongle: When he becomes Grand Duke, it will only get worse. Laws will change, freedoms will vanish, and soon you'll be accused and sentenced before you've even committed a crime.
Wulbren Bongle: And the fucking Gondians are to blame for all of it.
Player: Cheer up Wulbren. We're here to help.
Wulbren Bongle: I heard about that. You had the Harpers all excited, but there aren't many Harpers left.
Wulbren Bongle: These Steel Watchers. One of them is the equivalent of a red dragon. An army of them, well... there's never been an army of dragons.
Player: I'm sneaky - I'll keep clear of them.
Wulbren Bongle: They'll find you, and they'll kill you.
Wulbren Bongle: We need to stop them, and there's only one way to do it.
Wulbren Bongle: By hitting the Gondians. Hard.
Wulbren Bongle: They invented the Steel Watchers. And they're building an army of them.
Wulbren Bongle: They've always been happy to provide their technology to despots in exchange for a stipend and the freedom to work in peace.
Wulbren Bongle: They would have licked Sarevok's boots given the chance, and now they'll kiss Gortash's ring while the city screams.
Wulbren Bongle: I had a plan to put a stop to them. But the way things are now, if we stick our heads above ground, the Watchers are on us like flies on shit.
Player: What was the plan?
Wulbren Bongle: Same as it always is. Eliminate the threat.
Wulbren Bongle: In this case - the foundry where these atrocities are produced.
Wulbren Bongle: The Gondians are ingenious. But we're more than equal to them - there's nothing they can build that the Ironhands can't tear down.
Wulbren Bongle: I've built something unique for just that purpose.
Wulbren Bongle: A runepowder bomb - first of its kind. Fifty wizards high on the Weave couldn't summon this kind of firepower.
Wulbren Bongle: Get the bomb inside the Gondian facility, and - boom. Problem solved.
Barcus Wroot: Wulbren, please. This is too far! Everyone in the foundry would be killed.
Wulbren Bongle: Quiet, Barcus. The adults are talking.
Player: Killing innocents won't right this wrong, Wulbren.
Wulbren Bongle: Innocents. You have no idea what you're talking about.
Wulbren Bongle: The Gondians picked their side the minute they took orders from Gortash.
Wulbren Bongle: If they had any courage, they'd have refused him and died like heroes, spitting in his face.
Wulbren Bongle: Now they'll die like the dogs they are.
Player: I'll make contact with the Gondians - maybe they'll see reason.
Barcus Wroot: That's what I've been saying! There may yet be a peaceful solution.
Wulbren Bongle: Fine. You want to try flapping your gums in the belly of the beast, be my guest.
Wulbren Bongle: But their idea of diplomacy is a steel fist shoved where the sun don't shine.
Wulbren Bongle: So take the bomb. Just in case I'm right, and you're wrong.
Player: Keep your bomb. I'm doing this my way.

Wulbren Bongle: Good to see you. Wasn't sure you'd make it to the city. Regretting it yet?
Wulbren Bongle: I spent a lot of time thinking of worst case scenarios while I was locked in that cell you plucked me out of at Moonrise.
Wulbren Bongle: I didn't imagine anything as bad as this. The Gondians have handed Enver Gortash the means to bring about the end of liberty in Baldur's Gate.
Wulbren Bongle: And the citizens have rolled out the red carpet for their new tyrant.
Wulbren Bongle: Resistance fighters are few and far between - my Ironhands, what's left of the Harpers, and you. I hope.
Player: Gortash is a dead man - I have reasons of my own for taking him down.
Wulbren Bongle: As long as our objective is the same, the reason doesn't matter to me. We have a common enemy.
Wulbren Bongle: But neither of us gets what we want until we deal with our biggest obstacle.
Wulbren Bongle: The Steel Watch. They're a threat to you, me - and every man, woman and child in the city.
Wulbren Bongle: They act all civilised... servants of the people. But they only serve one man.
Wulbren Bongle: When he becomes Grand Duke, it will only get worse. Laws will change, freedoms will vanish, and soon you'll be accused and sentenced before you've even committed a crime.
Wulbren Bongle: And the fucking Gondians are to blame for all of it.
Player: The Gondians are just inventors. You can't blame them for Gortash's actions.
Wulbren Bongle: I can blame them for precisely that reason.
Player: I still don't buy it. Would you blame a mage for how the spells they wrote are used?
Wulbren Bongle: These Gondians are not poor, unknowing mages scribbling spell scrolls for Minute Meteors or Acid Arrows. They are complicit.
Wulbren Bongle: They've always been happy to provide their technology to despots in exchange for a stipend and the freedom to work in peace.
Wulbren Bongle: They would have licked Sarevok's boots given the chance, and now they'll kiss Gortash's ring while the city screams.
Wulbren Bongle: I had a plan to put a stop to them. But the way things are now, if we stick our heads above ground, the Watchers are on us like flies on shit.
Player: No plan survives contact with the enemy - unless I'm involved.
Wulbren Bongle: Exactly. You freed us from Ketheric's rotten cells - I reckon you can rid us of these Gondians just as easily.
Wulbren Bongle: You just need a little assistance, and I can provide it.
Wulbren Bongle: The Gondians are ingenious. But we're more than equal to them - there's nothing they can build that the Ironhands can't tear down.
Wulbren Bongle: I've built something unique for just that purpose.
Wulbren Bongle: A runepowder bomb - first of its kind. Fifty wizards high on the Weave couldn't summon this kind of firepower.
Wulbren Bongle: Get the bomb inside the Gondian facility, and - boom. Problem solved.

Wulbren Bongle: The Gondians picked their side the minute they took orders from Gortash.
Wulbren Bongle: If they had any courage, they'd have refused him and died like heroes, spitting in his face.
Wulbren Bongle: Now they'll die like the dogs they are.

Havkelaag: Well met. What can the Society of Brilliance do for you?
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now.
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. Your kind have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: Most on this plane believe you to be innately cruel, violent beings. Evil, if you will.
Havkelaag: As citizens of the Underdark, we face similar stigmas. Totally unfounded, of course - our natures are as unfixed as any who walk the surface.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: You're letting your personal biases affect your method. Why assume they're evil?
Havkelaag: I assume nothing. Innate githyanki cruelty is an established fact - no doubt you witnessed it yourself in the retrieval of the egg itself.
Havkelaag: When I have a suitable sample for my study, I will, however, prove that the effects of their biological inclination are reversible.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: So you're planning to torture a child for a year?
Havkelaag: The child will be a better individual after my treatment than it ever would have been had it been raised in its natural environment.
Havkelaag: Any suffering it endures will therefore be worth it, for the child, perhaps for the whole of civilised society.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: No benefit could justify you inflicting such cruelty.
Havkelaag: Rigorous experimental methods demand we do not indulge our own emotional responses in the application of discomfort to our subjects.
Havkelaag: Only by the full, uninhibited application of psionic stimuli will we have a true measure of whether the child's innate evil has been cured.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: Sell the egg.

Jaheira: The cult of the Absolute is spreading through the city - quietly, quickly, and with unsettling deliberation.

Shadowheart: Lady Shar does not see mercy as a virtue, even to simple creatures...
Shadowheart: I'll admit it, staying true to Lady Shar has proved difficult at times. I've found that my mind is prone to wandering.
Shadowheart: Wandering to places I shouldn't go, at that. Forbidden thoughts, hidden memories... all that Lady Shar would shield me from, until I am ready.
Shadowheart: Sometimes it feels like there's something just out of reach. Some truth, on the tip of my tongue. And at times, I feel like I can almost voice it.
Shadowheart: Thinking about my wound... it can't just be random, how it torments me. Surely there's a pattern, a purpose...
Shadowheart: When I ate the noblestalk, I remembered I had a friend. But all I have is a name, and a face. There must be more...

He Who Was: Madeline's spirit is within reach. It is time to make her face trial, to make her suffer.
He Who Was: And you will be the judge. Make her beg, make her suffer.
Player: Let's see what she has to say first.
He Who Was: Careful - for a serpent in life is a serpent in death.
He Who Was: Witness her.
NodeContext: low, excited voice. Eyes roll back in his head as he looks up - body jerking. Falls to his knees.
Madeline: You! He said I was gonna be punished, that you'd be the judge. But I didn't mean to hurt anyone!
Player: You 'didn't mean' to kill your friends? How laughable.
Madeline: I said it didn't mean nothin', that Ben n' Marc were just drunk n' whining.
Madeline: The Dark Justiciar promised she was gonna chat with 'em. She promised.
Player: What did the Dark Justiciar actually do to your friends?
Madeline: She gave 'em a dagger each, and told 'em to press it against their stomachs.
Madeline: On the count of three, to 'start stabbin', and not to stop 'til she said so.
Madeline: She never said stop. I'd do anything to take it back. Anything.
Player: Pathetic - you murdered your friends. You're a coward.

Player: I see some familiar faces, but where's everyone else?
Alfira: You don't know? Stars above...
Alfira: We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them.
Alfira: They lined us up like dogs. Ikaron was with the kids, telling them it was gonna be all right.

Alfira: Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel...
Alfira: They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: How did you survive?
Alfira: Rolan, of all people, saved us.
Alfira: He said he stayed in the grove because of you, and I'm damn glad of it. Without him... well, none of us would be here.
Player: I know - Rolan isn't happy with me.
Alfira: Can you blame him? His brother and sister are gone. He's... dealing with it as best he can. We all are.
Alfira: How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: I'll let you know when I figure it out.
Alfira: We're in the same boat, then? That's... somewhat of a comfort.
Alfira: You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there.
Alfira: If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: I imagine the cultists are torturing them right now.

Wulbren Bongle: The scent of runepowder drifts through the city like a warm embrace - I see my bomb did the trick.
Wulbren Bongle: Watchers collapse in the street as we speak. The city thanks you - I thank you.

Gondian Zanner Toobin: Take the city - let the Ironhands reign supreme. I just wish to go home and mourn my daughter in peace.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Take the city - let the Ironhands reign supreme. I just wish to go home, and to hold my daughter.
Player: He's right. It's over.

Barcus Wroot: I thought the Ironhand Gnomes had corrupted you, Wulbren. Now I wonder if it wasn't the other way around.
Barcus Wroot: Kill the Gondians, and you kill all we love: Collaboration. Challenge. Solving problems with the power of reason, creativity, and invention.
Barcus Wroot: I still want to believe you're better than that, Wulbren. But even I am having my doubts.
Player: Sorry, Toobin - I guess this is it for you.

Zethino: You return, stira - good. Violence is like fire - it burns all those in its path. I feared you caught in the flames.
Zethino: Do you wish to speak of love, little one? For Zethino is here to help - always. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Zethino: You return, stira. I pray the hearts of you and your companion are ready - for love is a fragile blossom, and we will test its resilience. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Player: How about it, Lae'zel? Want to give it a go?
Lae'zel: Yes. But be warned - I play to win.
Zethino: Ah. Glorious. Your bond is sweeter than nature's dew. I see you. Know you. But do you know one another?
Zethino: Shadowheart: an endless storm surges behind sharp eyes.
Zethino: Listen. Think. From where does Shadowheart draw comfort on a cold, dark night?
Player: Good company and an even better vintage.
Shadowheart: Well put. Though I'll forgive a middling wine so long as the company makes up the difference...
NodeContext: Flirty/playful. Company being the player.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player makes the first step towards the companion
Zethino: Your bond beats in pleasure. It is an honour to behold.
