Player: Being discreet.
Shadowheart: Very good. (Just don't say it so loud.)
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player takes a second step, moving even closer to the center for the trunk to the companion.
Zethino: Our touch has been that of sunlight, but now we must ask the deep. The difficult.
Zethino: Shame sits in the soul of all - to tame it, we must name it. Shadowheart - what is her deepest shame?
Player: Her hair.

Havkelaag: Ah, a surface dweller.
Havkelaag: You find yourself in the cradle of all knowledge relating to the Underdark: the Society of Brilliance.
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I met an expeditioner claiming to work for you. She sought a githyanki egg.
Havkelaag: Yes, dear Lady Esther. One of our most reliable contractors, though unfortunately this particular request was too much even for her.
Havkelaag: I believe she quite lost her senses over the task. She came here insisting I purchase an owlbear egg from her, of all things.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you've stumbled across any githyanki eggs during your travels? The Society will compensate you for any we purchase, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You are no doubt aware that citizens of the Underdark are held in great suspicion by those who live above ground. Many believe us to be 'evil'.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: You're letting your personal biases affect your method. Why assume they're evil?
Havkelaag: I assume nothing. Innate githyanki cruelty is an established fact - no doubt you witnessed it yourself in the retrieval of the egg itself.
Havkelaag: When I have a suitable sample for my study, I will, however, prove that the effects of their biological inclination are reversible.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: So you, too, follow the teachings of Bahamut. Why him?
Havkelaag: In my years of study, they're the closest I've found to moral perfection. Only under such rigorous 'goodness' will the subject stand a chance of being cured.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: No benefit could justify you inflicting such cruelty.
Havkelaag: Rigorous experimental methods demand we do not indulge our own emotional responses in the application of discomfort to our subjects.
Havkelaag: Only by the full, uninhibited application of psionic stimuli will we have a true measure of whether the child's innate evil has been cured.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: Sell the egg.

Yurgir: You trying to burrow back home, little rabbit?

Yurgir: Only what I can smell. And whatever engine burns within you is grinding to an inevitable explosion. Burning and fear - you reek with it.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down.
Player: Let's not let an ancient squabble interfere with the task at hand.
Isobel: Not as ancient as you think.
Isobel: Frankly, I'm surprised you're willing to help us. Your kind aren't known for their decency - particularly when a Sharran curse is our greatest obstacle.
Isobel: But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: I may have the parasite of a True Soul, but not the mind of one.
Isobel: And that's what makes you essential.
Isobel: You'll be needing the protection spell, I presume?
Isobel: Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: I am already protected. My Lady shields me from the curse.
Isobel: For now, perhaps. But Shar can be fickle, and her love can prove fleeting. Do not turn your back on an advantage you may need... even a Selûnite one.
Isobel: If nothing else, it can aid any companions who travel with you - somehow I doubt Shar's largesse was extended to them.
Player: Try to understand what's happening.
Narrator: *Is Lady Shar punishing you? Or perhaps testing you? Is it the tadpole, or a curse? You cannot say.*
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance.
Isobel: This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is.
Isobel: Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: The Dark Lady's works aren't for me to question.
Isobel: Mustn't question the great shadow mother, must we?
Isobel: I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: I've already been to Moonrise, but I have more work to do indeed.
Isobel: I imagine so, if Jaheira hasn't gone tearing off into the night.
Player: Wait - Marcus is a True Soul, you know. And not the good kind, like me.

Halsin: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic.
Halsin: Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: I spoke to Nettie - she said you could help me with the parasite in my head.
Halsin: Parasite in your head...? You mean you have one of them?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows what’s inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn.
Halsin: But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do...
Halsin: How is this possible...?
Player: I don't know.
Halsin: You weren't speaking lightly when you said you needed help. Let me tell you what I know.
Halsin: I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them.
Halsin: Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected.
Halsin: I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help.
Halsin: I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from.
Halsin: That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: You learned all this from your studies?
Halsin: Indeed. After we dealt with the drow that ambushed us, Nettie and I were able to inspect the corpse - and the creature that slithered out of it.
Halsin: I had no idea anyone beyond their ranks was infected. You have my sincere sympathies.
Player: This magic you mentioned - it isn't normal for these parasites?
Player: What should I do?
Halsin: I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers.
Halsin: Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic.
Halsin: If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: At least I know what to do now. Thank you.
Halsin: Wait - I could help you find a cure... but I need to settle matters here first.
Halsin: I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise.
Halsin: I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: The other druids are dead, by my hand.
Halsin: What...? How? Why?! Explain yourself at once!
Player: They left me no choice. I had to defend myself.
Halsin: Then... then it is as you say. They forgot their principles; you had no choice. I will mourn them when I can.
Halsin: But there are other matters to attend to before that.
Halsin: Chaos is welcome, in doses; it helps keep balance. But this is too much - this is unnatural.
Halsin: It's too late to merely kill this horde's leadership - their forces are already marching. If you want me to help, you need to help me first.
Halsin: You must get ahead of them, muster the defences.
Player: Very well. I'll go rescue the grove.

Player: Do the right thing. Give your soul so that your father can live.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: I am no student, I seek knowledge of the curse. It is a blight on this land.
Malus Thorm: A curse? Nay, a cure that leads to the very pinnacle of being:
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Lae'zel: Only a beast of a man toys with his victim. Entertaining, if not efficient.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.

Karlach: If you'd just hear me out -

Narrator: *Her rage and desperation seep into you. She is a victim of the Blood War, not an agent of it.*

Karlach: Look, whatever else it may be, the tadpole isn't a liar. I never wanted to serve Zariel, and I escaped the first chance I could. So stand down.

Lorroakan: You have a job to do. So do it - quickly.
Player: You must be the wizard Lorroakan. I've heard a great deal about you.
Lorroakan: My - could it be? Gale of Waterdeep, here in my tower. I'm surprised you dare show your face after Mystra cast you on the scrap heap.
Lorroakan: Well don't stand on ceremony - out with it.
Player: I seek a certain rare tome - concerning Karsus.
Lorroakan: You're quite in luck, then - see Tolna downstairs. One such tome is amongst our rarest books.
Lorroakan: But enough of dusty history - I look to the future.
Lorroakan: You know I seek the Nightsong. Do you have it or not?
Player: What do you want with her?

Lorroakan: Tell me - and choose your next words carefully - where is she now?
Player: Be careful what you wish for. She'll eat you alive.
Lorroakan: I'm growing tired of this repartee, my friend. Let us cut to the chase.
Lorroakan: Beautiful, isn't it? Worth more than your life, too. I bought it from a Calishite warlock with very little of his soul left to him.
Lorroakan: It can bind a celestial to the wearer's service with a snap of the fingers.
Lorroakan: And this? This can keep her in place. Forever.
Player: First Ketheric, now you - there are easier ways to achieve immortality, you know.
Player: A clever contraption. Let me guess: like Ketheric Thorm before you, you wish to become immortal.
Lorroakan: It didn't work out for poor Ketheric, did it? He was a fool. A desperate mercenary who whored out his soul to whichever god flattered him.
Lorroakan: I serve no god but that which stares back at me in the mirror.
Lorroakan: The Nightsong will be put to a grand purpose: equalising man and god. Whoever helps me attain that which I seek will be greatly rewarded.
Player: You're an arrogant fool. Immortality alone does not make a god.
Lorroakan: Of course not. But perhaps, after enough lifetimes, I might make a start of it.
Lorroakan: When I succeed, I may look favourably upon you. If you are a friend along the way, that is.
Lorroakan: And this? This can keep her in place. Forever.
Player: First Ketheric and now you. I thought wizards were supposed to be the smart ones?

Jaheira: Our enemies spread like rub-rot - treat one patch, and two more bloom in its place.
Jaheira: An elder brain, bound by lost Netherese magic, with servants of the Dead Three holding the chain.
Jaheira: Reminds me of old times.
Player: You almost seem like you're enjoying yourself.
Jaheira: Aren't you?
Player: I'm beginning to.
Jaheira: When we met, I was licking my wounds - an old bear with her leg caught in the hunter's snare.
Jaheira: Now, I've slipped free of the trap and rediscovered my claws.
Jaheira: It's time for me to hunt my prey.
Jaheira: You have a Netherstone, and you're on the scent of two more.
Jaheira: These Chosen have reason to fear you - and I would like to be at your side when you confront them.
Player: I'll be glad to have you by my side.
Jaheira: Glad to be there.
Jaheira: Falling foul of Ketheric convinced me that my grand adventures were behind me - that even if I survived, I should hang up my blades.
Jaheira: But you convinced me otherwise.
Jaheira: You ventured into the heart of darkness when I could not.
Jaheira: When we reach Baldur's Gate, there will be even darker paths to tread. I will follow you wherever they lead.
Player: I'll see you at camp.

Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I met an expeditioner claiming to work for you. She sought a githyanki egg.
Havkelaag: Yes, dear Lady Esther. One of our most reliable contractors, though unfortunately this particular request was too much even for her.
Havkelaag: I believe she quite lost her senses over the task. She came here insisting I purchase an owlbear egg from her, of all things.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you've stumbled across any githyanki eggs during your travels? The Society will compensate you for any we purchase, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You are no doubt aware that citizens of the Underdark are held in great suspicion by those who live above ground. Many believe us to be 'evil'.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: What does this 'intellectually stimulating' upbringing look like?
Havkelaag: In the literal sense, I will need to induce the egg to hatch via the application of certain currents to the creature inside.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: You would teach the child virtue, but rear it without patience. Curious.
Havkelaag: Tell me, then, philosopher - if patience delays the fostering of the other virtues, can it be rightly called virtuous?
Player: Patience does not delay, it simply tempers virtue. Curtails it from excess.
Havkelaag: A cautious, hesitant instinct. One I am afraid we do not have time for.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: Sounds pointless. Public opinion will hardly be swayed by such a small experiment.
Havkelaag: Not at first. But if the experiment proves successful, it must be repeated. Only then will we know if the findings are to be trusted.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: This experiment is barbaric. You're never getting the egg.

Rugan: By the gods, you're a sweet sight.
Rugan: Are any of my crew still alive out there?
Player: No. It's a grim sight.
Rugan: This whole journey's been one grim sight after another. Gnolls, goblins... drow.
Rugan: Risen Road's more dangerous than ever. You're the first friendly face we've seen since Elturgard.
Player: Elturgard's a long way from here. Where are you heading?
Rugan: We're bound for Baldur's Gate - got some cargo to deliver. But we've a stop to make along the way.
Player: Maybe I should come - see you don't get waylaid again.
Rugan: Thanks. But that won't be necessary. We'll find help at Waukeen's Rest.
Rugan: Listen. You look like you know how to handle yourself.
Rugan: You should meet my associates. We've got our own drinking spot by the tavern - invitation only.
Rugan: Tell the fellow on the door 'little serpent, long shadow'. He'll take good care of you.
Olly: Rugan!
Rugan: It's fine. We'd be dead if they hadn't showed up. A little hospitality won't do any harm.
Player: Read his thoughts.
: True
Rugan: Shame we lost so many agents. But the chest is all that matters - Zarys'd have our hides if we lost it.
Rugan: It's fine. We'd be dead if they hadn't showed up. A little hospitality won't do any harm.
Player: What's in the chest? Your cargo?

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down.
Player: I thought I smelled a Selûnite.
Isobel: At your service.
Isobel: Frankly, I'm surprised you're willing to help us. Your kind aren't known for their decency - particularly when a Sharran curse is our greatest obstacle.
Isobel: But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: I won't be spoken to like that by a Selûnite.
Isobel: We've both got a bitter pill to swallow. When this is all over, we can spit it back out.
Isobel: You'll be needing the protection spell, I presume?
Isobel: Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: Nod. Better to humour her than make an enemy of all in this place. Lady Shar will understand.
Isobel: Refreshingly pragmatic of you. I sense Shar has offered some amount of protection to you already, but... well, no harm in extra precaution - even from a Selûnite.
Player: Silently petition Lady Shar for guidance.
Narrator: *She offers you nothing.*
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance.
Isobel: This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is.
Isobel: It won't be enough to protect you against areas of utter darkness, though - where the curse is strongest. This lantern should, though.
Player: Very nice of you, but I've been to Moonrise Towers already.
Isobel: You... have. Forgive me for gilding the lily. I suppose if Jaheira hasn't gone tearing into the night, there's work to be done there yet.
Isobel: I wish you luck. The very best of it.
Player: Hold on - Marcus is a True Soul. He's here to kidnap you.

Abdirak: Greetings, child. I've met few aside from goblins here.
NodeContext: Player is one of the few non-goblins he's met in this place. Welcomes another for conversation and discussion but there should be something vaguely threatening about him. Charismatic, sexy, and creepy all in one.
Player: InternalNodeContext: A player with the CLERIC or PALADIN tag will have this flag set alreay before starting the dialog, so they bypass the passive check
: True

Abdirak: Ah, are you also here to assist with the prisoner?
Player: I'm only passing through.
Abdirak: Your tastes must turn to the exotic, if you would stop here by choice.
Abdirak: I was invited to discuss pain and its intricacies, but even I find these goblins crude and, well - primitive.
Abdirak: Pain without purpose is a terrible thing, wouldn't you agree?
Player: As Vlaakith says: we cannot know pleasure without pain.
Abdirak: Exactly, pain is an intimate thing. It should be delivered with a loving and measured hand.
Abdirak: But trying to discuss such subtleties with these creatures is simply...
Abdirak: Forgive me, but that look in your eyes - something terrible has happened to you.
Player: I'm trying to resist my drive to do harm, but it's very difficult.
Abdirak: Do not be ashamed, child. What I see in your eyes, in your soul, is only natural.
Abdirak: We've all suffered in these dark times. It is little wonder you bear scars of pain and anguish.
Abdirak: Please let me alleviate this pain.
Player: I know of your penance - my companion has tried it.
Abdirak: Ah, but of course!
Abdirak: Well, perhaps you'd be interested in finishing what they started?
Abdirak: Care to expand your horizons? It will be worth it - you have my word.
Lae'zel: By all means - let us see what his 'skilled hand' might get up to.
Player: Prepare for the coming pain.
Abdirak: Oh, I have something exquisite in mind.

Lorin: No... No. Don't look. Musn'tlook. Musn'tsee.

Lorin: Ah! Gods! Don't hurt me. Oh, please, please pleasepleaseplease.

Lorin: Not drow. Neverdrow. Monster. MONSTER.
Lorin: Mindripping, fleshpeeling. MIND FLAYER.

Shirra Clarwen: Who, now, shall bear the madness Shar has wrought on me, so I might no longer suffer?
Shirra Clarwen: He-ho-hoo-haHAHAHAHAHA! Shall it be - THOU?
Player: If it will bring you peace, I will bear the madness.
Shirra Clarwen: HOO!
Narrator: *Your muscles tingle and your mouth twitches as the laughing madness spreads through you.*
Narrator: *The madness tugs at your mind, prods in places best left untouched. You feel your wisdom begin to drain...*

: True
Narrator: *You remain wise as ever, even as Shar's madness spreads outward.*
Narrator: *You giggle, struck by the absurdity of the moment. A spirit hiding inside an amulet has brought you to the body of his granddaughter and possessed it. Outrageous! Ridiculous!*
Narrator: *Once again, you feel your wisdom draining away. Hilarious! Or is it?*
Player: Muster your senses, clear your mind. You will take the madness, but it will not take of you.

Narrator: *The urge to laugh dwindles, though you can't help but chuckle. You withstood the monk's madness and earned Tasha's Hideous Laughter.*

Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.
Halsin: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic.
Halsin: Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: Glad I could be of help.
Halsin: I must admit, I didn't expect anyone would come to my aid. Who in their right mind would infiltrate a goblin infested temple. Unless...
Halsin: ...Hrrm. That look in your eyes - I've seen it before. Are you feeling all right?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows what’s inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn.
Halsin: But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do...
Halsin: How is this possible...?
Player: I think this artefact has something to do with it.
Halsin: Hmmm... that looks very alien. As alien as the mind flayers. They do not belong on this world.
Halsin: You weren't speaking lightly when you said you needed help. Let me tell you what I know.
Halsin: I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them.
Halsin: Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected.
Halsin: I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help.
Halsin: I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from.
Halsin: That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: So all of this was for nothing.
Halsin: Patience. I can't just snap my fingers... but I know where the solution almost certainly lies.
Halsin: I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers.
Halsin: Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic.
Halsin: If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: Altered parasites? A cure at Moonrise Towers, maybe? Sounds like guesswork at best.
Halsin: I'm as certain as I can be. If you have a better alternative, I won't stop you.
Halsin: I can't stop you, in fact. Which brings me to my next problem...
Halsin: I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise.
Halsin: I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: All right. How do I help?
Halsin: My thanks. If you prevail, I'll owe you the debt of a lifetime.
Halsin: Rare is the beast that survives decapitation. Help me eliminate the drow Minthara, the hobgoblin Dror Ragzlin, and that perversion of a priestess, Gut.
Halsin: They are the ones holding these parasites together. Remove them and nature will cure itself.
Player: I'll deal with this. You get to safety.
Halsin: I told you, nowhere is safe. Not while this rot festers. Once it is cut out - once the grove is secure - then I shall leave.
Player: Follow me, then. Your bear form may prove useful.
Halsin: Be warned - my presence could make things more difficult... I can only restrain my bear form so much. I won't be able to help but attack goblins.
Halsin: If I join you, we'll likely have to slaughter this entire place. You may want to use discretion when approaching the goblin leaders.
Player: Stay here.

Player: What is this place?

Ptaris: I am Ptaris. And I am good.
Ptaris: Father was bad. They all were. I tried to make them better, but they were not strong enough. They lacked resolve.
Player: What did they do that was so terrible?
Ptaris: They did not live up to father's code. Even he did not follow it correctly.
Ptaris: He was not righteous. He was not innocent. His thoughts were impure.
Ptaris: Such evil can only be cured one way. With pain. With torment. And if that does not work - with death.
Ptaris: Tell me - are you a good person?

Ptaris: It is honour. Justice. The true form of goodness we all must live by, decreed by Bahamut himself.
Ptaris: You are not capable of following its teachings.
Ptaris: I know what you did to me. I see the memory of it, right there in your head.
Ptaris: You stole me from my people. Gave me to that woman. Unhatched, defenceless. You let me be brought here so father could hurt me.
Lae'zel: A githyanki raised in isolation. His blood boils like his kin's, but their ways are foreign.
Ptaris: You are bad. You must be taught a lesson.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: You will stop this sick spectacle at once.
Malus Thorm: Sick. Quite. But on the cusp of a cure:
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Wyll: Hells. Only a monster would inflict misery and call it medicine.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes you. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: The sisters aren't ready. They'll make me sick instead of curing me.
: True
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Practice - that's how I got good with a blade. They should spar each other.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?
Malus Thorm: The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey.
Malus Thorm: Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart.
Malus Thorm: You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure.
Malus Thorm: Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: You do me an honour, but I am not worthy. Show me the way of Shar - I beg of you.
Player: I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
: True
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be.

Halsin: This doesn't have to be your burden alone. Every moment counts, and I've asked much of you already without being at your side.
Halsin: If you want me, I'm yours. Against the curse, against the Absolute - anything. Just say the word.
Player: I met a sort of shadow child before - a little boy named Oliver. Around Thaniel's age.
Halsin: And you saw this boy yourself? That can't be a coincidence - but we need to be sure.
Halsin: And I truly mean we, if you wish. Every moment counts, and I've asked much of you already without being at your side.
Halsin: There is a ruin, some way outside of Last Light. I caught a glimpse of fresh blooms there, but did not investigate further. I shall mark it upon your map.
Player: I'll see what I can do, but no promises.
Halsin: Let me help you then. Every moment counts, and I've asked much of you already without being at your side.
Halsin: If you want me, I'm yours. Against the curse, against the Absolute - anything. Just say the word.
Player: Join me.
Halsin: Good. Now our roots can deepen - together.

Questioner Sumera: You were adored, Minthara. Brought up from the darkness, and into the Absolute's light.
Questioner Jasin: She cherished you. But it wasn't enough - you were distracted by your own desires.
Questioner Sumera: Bloodlust. Murder. Chaos.
Questioner Jasin: And most damning of all, an inability to follow orders.
Nightwarden Minthara: I obeyed to the best of my ability.
Questioner Sumera: And isn't that depressing?
Questioner Jasin: You are nothing.
Narrator: *The drow reaches out to you psychically, connecting with you for a moment. She is infected, like you, and her mind is disintegrating.*
Questioner Sumera: Come to observe, True Soul? She is a lesson - none can rise so high that they cannot fall again.
Player: I expected her to be dismembered. Disappointing.
Questioner Sumera: When the body suffers, we retreat into the mind. But when the mind breaks, all is lost.
Questioner Sumera: We are erasing her.
Player: I've been instructed to handle this prisoner myself.
: True
Questioner Sumera: No - this is our duty.
Questioner Jasin: Peace, sister. Let us observe the True Soul's methods - perhaps we can learn from them.
Questioner Jasin: Her mind is yours. Break it.
Player: Reach out for Minthara's mind.
Narrator: *Immediately, your mind is swept into a greater vortex. A psionic storm with Minthara at its centre.*
GROUP_GLO_VoiceOfTheAbsolute: -CANNOT-
                   -hide-
-SUBMIT-
                   -embrace-

Narrator: *Her torturers are not dominating her - they are destroying her mental defences, and exposing her to the presence that claims to be the Absolute.*
Player: Push past the presence, towards Minthara.
: True
Narrator: *Navigating the storm, you reach the nexus of her mind. It is a wound, bleeding raw emotion and shattered memories. But she senses your arrival.*
Nightwarden Minthara: So it is you who will end me.
Nightwarden Minthara: Make it swift, then. Anything to silence that thing - that voice.
Player: I have a plan - fake obedience, and the guards will leave without raising the alarm.
Nightwarden Minthara: I would prefer to make these bastards bleed, but I trust that you speak from caution rather than cowardice.
Nightwarden Minthara: I will put my faith in you, and pretend to be their slave.
Questioner Jasin: Is it done? I did not feel her mind break.
Player: Look at her. The True Soul Minthara you knew is gone.
: True
Questioner Sumera: She does look a little... vacant, sister.
Questioner Jasin: No more anger, no more doubt. She is perfect.
Questioner Jasin: We ought to return to our posts, sister. There'll be plenty more prisoners to practice on.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: # Shorter Appearance Sequence #
Wyll: Holy hells.
Player: Please, introduce me to your friends.
Mizora: Feena, Cirrus. Arbiters for the Hells, exemplars of justice.
Mizora: I come to bargain. The Hells demand witness.
Narrator: *Your parasite links with Wyll's, and your memories flow into him. He sees his father's flight from Wyrm's Rock and hears Mizora's words to you.*
Wyll: Father is dead? Godsdamned devil. Why are you here?
Mizora: Sisters.
Arbiter Cirrus: Infernus contractus te vocamus. Infernus contractus te vocamus. Infernus contractus te vocamus.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: A contract appears in the air, glowing. It is Wyll's contract.
Mizora: Your contract, Wyll. Signed in blood, forged in fire, bound in bone - but not unbreakable.
Player: Remain silent.
Mizora: Yet no contract is ended without sacrifice, Wyll. The cost must be paid.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Flames ignite Mizora and her two companions. Mizora's voice echos outward as if amplified by the Hells themselves.
Mizora: Wyll Ravengard. A choice is before you.
Mizora: Option one. I show you the way to your father. I guarantee him no harm except that from you and your allies. And you pledge your soul to me and the archdevil Zariel in a pact eternal.
Mizora: Option two. I break your pact. You are freed from your duty but retain your devil form. Your father dies by his enemy's hand.
Mizora: Name your sacrifice.
Karlach: Bloody Zariel. I won't let her take Wyll!
Mizora: Silence, Karlach!
Wyll: Mizora, you arsehole.
Mizora: Choose.
Player: Bring back your father, Wyll. The city will need him to help rebuild.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.
Player: May Shar guide your blessing hands.
Malus Thorm: And the rough vessels that are yours.
Malus Thorm: Tell me, what is the guiding principle of the goddess?
Player: Forgetfulness.
Malus Thorm: I profess there is another more profound.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Lae'zel: Only a beast of a man toys with his victim. Entertaining, if not efficient.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: You are well on your way. But one white orb disfigures you still. Let us finish the cure.
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: The goddess has greater plans for me than to submit to your scalpels.
: True
Malus Thorm: Another absence is your fate? But if you are not here to be cured, how will my sisters learn?
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Sparring is vital to progress. Have them practice on each other.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?
Malus Thorm: The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey.
Malus Thorm: Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart.
Malus Thorm: You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure.
Malus Thorm: Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: You do me an honour, but I am not worthy. Show me the way of Shar - I beg of you.
Player: I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
: True
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be.

Narrator: *Your father, once the Grand Duke, now a pawn in the Absolute's game. Your infected minds smoulder in each others' presence.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: My dearest boy. The Hells have touched you. But you've come to me - just as Gortash said you would.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Father and son, unstoppable generals. Together, we will usher in a new dawn.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Have you come to behold the new dawn?
Player: I'm here to help you. Florrick sent me.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Help me? Ah - the black widow caught you in her web.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Florrick chose shadow over light. Her betrayal burned deeper than the fires of Avernus.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: She's been punished for her lies. Don't let her get to you.
Narrator: *The Duke wants to keep Florrick's location a secret. Little does he know that you've already found and freed her.*
Player: Connect with Ravengard's parasite to seek information about Florrick.
: True

Duke Ulder Ravengard: Have you come to behold the new dawn?
Player: I'm here to help you. Florrick sent me.

Player: What have you done to Florrick?
Duke Ulder Ravengard: The sun rises, True Soul. Are you ready?
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Have you come to behold the new dawn?
Player: My father, my hero. I'll save you from the Absolute's thrall.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: What is a hero, if not an actor for the greater good?
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Faerûn suffers in darkness. Tyr has abandoned us; Helm's eye has strayed.
Narrator: *Tyr's fury glows within you. Despite Ravengard's words, the Lord of Justice has remained loyal to you, as you have to him.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: But Baldur's Gate will soon burn bright. A beacon to light the heavens.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: And it will be Gortash who ignites the final spark.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Have you come to behold the new dawn?
Player: By the gods, what have they made of the city's great hero?

Ptaris: You - you don't look like them. You look like me. Who are you?
Player: A githyanki? What are you doing down here?
Ptaris: I am not a githyanki. Do not call me that!
Ptaris: I am Ptaris. And I am good.
Ptaris: Father was bad. They all were. I tried to make them better, but they were not strong enough. They lacked resolve.
Player: So you killed them?
Ptaris: It is not my fault they died. I was only upholding father's code. Even he was not strong enough to follow it.
Ptaris: He was not righteous. He was not innocent. His thoughts were impure.
Ptaris: Such evil can only be cured one way. With pain. With torment. And if that does not work - with death.
Ptaris: Tell me - are you a good person?
Player: I try to be, but sometimes my magic has other ideas.
Ptaris: There is no 'try'. You are either good or you are not.
Ptaris: The Ptarian Code must be obeyed. This is the only way to be sure. Do you follow it?
Player: No one code can define goodness. It's impossible.
Ptaris: Only a bad person would say that. And that's what you are.
Ptaris: I know what you did to me. I see the memory of it, right there in your head.
Ptaris: You stole me from my people. Gave me to that woman. Unhatched, defenceless. You let me be brought here so father could hurt me.
Lae'zel: A githyanki raised in isolation. His blood boils like Vlaakith's, but he knows nothing of the Protocols.
Ptaris: You are bad. You must be taught a lesson.
NodeContext: Like this is the onyl reasonable conclusion
Player: I thought I was saving you. I had no idea what they were planning.
Player: You would have been destroyed if not for me. I saved you.
: True
Ptaris: You were trying to save me? I - I don't understand.

Ptaris: I am Ptaris. And I am good.
Ptaris: Father was bad. They all were. I tried to make them better, but they were not strong enough. They lacked resolve.
Player: Was Lady Esther bad too?
Ptaris: She did not have the strength to be good. She was another like father - lacking in moral fibre.
NodeContext: Indifferent to the dead body at his feet.
Ptaris: He was not righteous. He was not innocent. His thoughts were impure.
Ptaris: Such evil can only be cured one way. With pain. With torment. And if that does not work - with death.
Ptaris: Tell me - are you a good person?

Ptaris: If you only think, then you do not know.
Ptaris: The Ptarian Code must be obeyed. This is the only way to be sure. Do you follow it?
Player: The code of Bahamut. His guidance leads me in all things.

Ptaris: I know what you did to me. I see the memory of it, right there in your head.
Ptaris: You stole me from my people. Gave me to that woman. Unhatched, defenceless. You let me be brought here so father could hurt me.

Wyll: Holy hells.
Player: Come to gloat, Mizora? We found a letter claiming Ravengard died.
Mizora: I come to bargain. The Hells demand witness.
Narrator: *Your parasite links with Wyll's, and your memories flow into him. He sees his father's flight from Wyrm's Rock and hears Mizora's words to you.*
Wyll: Enough, Mizora. My father is dead. Say your piece.
Mizora: Sisters.
Arbiter Cirrus: Infernus contractus te vocamus. Infernus contractus te vocamus. Infernus contractus te vocamus.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: A contract appears in the air, glowing. It is Wyll's contract.
Mizora: Your contract, Wyll. Signed in blood, forged in fire, bound in bone - but not unbreakable.
Player: Then break it already. Wyll has suffered enough.
Mizora: No contract is ended without sacrifice. A cost must be paid.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Flames ignite Mizora and her two companions. Mizora's voice echos outward as if amplified by the Hells themselves.
Mizora: Wyll Ravengard. A choice is before you.
Mizora: Option one. I raise your father from the dead. And you pledge your soul to me and the archdevil Zariel in a pact eternal.
Mizora: Option two. I break your pact, and you are freed from your duty. Your father remains dead, and Baldur's Gate loses its greatest champion.
Mizora: Name your sacrifice.
Karlach: Bloody Zariel. I won't let her take Wyll!
Wyll: Mizora, you arsehole.
Mizora: Choose.
Player: Save your father, Wyll. The city will need him to help rebuild.

Crusher: But no more. Things're changin'. We got the Absolute on our side now.

Crusher: Ya better learn yer place.
Crusher: Go on: kiss my foot.
NodeContext: bullying the player, he feels like they won't dare to refuse.
Crusher: Or I'll wipe that nasty look right off yer dirty face.

Player: NO. KISS MY FOOT.

NodeContext: grovelling. He realised he was talking down to someone of higher status.

Narrator: *His lips smack together wetly and leave a trail of saliva on your foot.*

Zethino: This city of stone and steel is an endless scream in nature's womb. I have felt no peace here. Until now.
Zethino: Your eyes, stira. There is pain, endless and deep. But also devotion - blazing like the sun. You're in love, are you not?
Player: I do love someone - someone close to me, actually.
Zethino: You are wise to admit it. When it comes to love, vulnerability is armour. Truth, a sword. And trust, a shield. I pray you wield all three, stira.
Zethino: Bring the one you love to me. I will look into your hearts and see if your love is eternal. Or doomed eternally. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Player: How about it, Lae'zel? Want to give it a go?
Lae'zel: Yes. But be warned - I play to win.
Zethino: Lae'zel: passions of the heart and the blade wage war in her soul.
Zethino: Listen. Think. What does she most desire?
Player: To find the truth about Orpheus amidst her queen's lies.
Lae'zel: You hear my words, you see my path. It is good to be known.
Lae'zel: You know me as I know myself. Glory be to my queen.
Zethino: Hear how your bond thrums with pleasure. Strong. Vital. Pulsing with affection.
Zethino: The heart craves comfort, but needs respect. How does one earn the dark-haired maiden's respect?

Shadowheart: Very good. (Just don't say it so loud.)

Abdirak: Greetings, child. I've met few aside from goblins here.
NodeContext: Player is one of the few non-goblins he's met in this place. Welcomes another for conversation and discussion but there should be something vaguely threatening about him. Charismatic, sexy, and creepy all in one.
Player: InternalNodeContext: A player with the CLERIC or PALADIN tag will have this flag set alreay before starting the dialog, so they bypass the passive check
: True
Narrator: *You recognise the scourge - this man is a follower of Loviatar, goddess of pain.*
Abdirak: Ah, are you also here to assist with the prisoner?
Player: What do you mean?
Abdirak: I was invited to teach them some of my... techniques. I live for pain and its intricacies, you see.
Abdirak: But alas, these goblins seem to thrive on the crude and primitive.
Abdirak: Pain without purpose is a terrible thing, wouldn't you agree?
Player: As long as the story ends in death, it's all the same to me.
Abdirak: Forgive me, but that look in your eyes - something terrible has happened to you.
Player: I'm trying to resist my drive to do harm, but it's very difficult.
Abdirak: Do not be ashamed, child. What I see in your eyes, in your soul, is only natural.
Abdirak: We've all suffered in these dark times. It is little wonder you bear scars of pain and anguish.
Abdirak: Please let me alleviate this pain.
Player: Why are you so interested?
Abdirak: Well - the Maiden of Pain, Loviatar, teaches us that pain is a most powerful and sacred sensation.
Abdirak: And should our pain delight her - should we embrace such a gift - she will grant her most sacred of blessings.
Abdirak: If you would permit it, I can show you first-hand.
Astarion: I must see this. Don't you dare say no.
Player: All right, why not?
Abdirak: Oh, I have something exquisite in mind.

Ptaris: Who are you? Another who needs to learn the difference between right and wrong?

Esther the expeditioner: S_GLO_Expeditioner_5f4048ba-72ef-43c2-9528-1c9a12f3f82f
Narrator: *A githyanki youth, and a familiar one at that. Can it be that this is the one who hatched from the egg you took from the crèche?*
Player: It's nice to see you again, githyanki.
Ptaris: I am not a githyanki. Do not call me that!
Ptaris: I am Ptaris. And I am good.
Ptaris: Father was bad. They all were. I tried to make them better, but they were not strong enough. They lacked resolve.
Player: Who was your father?
Ptaris: Havkelaag. He brought me from the shell. Raised me quickly. Taught me to be good. But he failed me.
Ptaris: He was not righteous. He was not innocent. His thoughts were impure.
Ptaris: Such evil can only be cured one way. With pain. With torment. And if that does not work - with death.
Ptaris: Tell me - are you a good person?
Player: I try to be. For I serve a greater power - one who embodies everything good in this world.
Ptaris: There is no 'try'. You are either good or you are not.
Ptaris: The Ptarian Code must be obeyed. This is the only way to be sure. Do you follow it?
Player: I follow my gut. That's all anyone can do.
Ptaris: Your gut cannot be trusted. That is why the code exists. That is why you failed.
Ptaris: I know what you did to me. I see the memory of it, right there in your head.
Ptaris: You stole me from my people. Gave me to that woman. Unhatched, defenceless. You let me be brought here so father could hurt me.
Lae'zel: A githyanki raised in isolation. His blood boils like his kin's, but their ways are foreign.
Ptaris: You are bad. You must be taught a lesson.
NodeContext: Like this is the onyl reasonable conclusion
Player: Ungrateful yank. Our kin would have destroyed you if it wasn't for me.
Player: You would have been destroyed if not for me. I saved you.
: True
Ptaris: You were trying to save me? I - I don't understand.

Havkelaag: Ah, a fellow inhabitor of the Underdark.
Havkelaag: You find yourself in the cradle of all knowledge relating to our subterranean home: the Society of Brilliance.
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now.
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. Your kind have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: Most on this plane believe you to be innately cruel, violent beings. Evil, if you will.
Havkelaag: As citizens of the Underdark, we face similar stigmas. Totally unfounded, of course - our natures are as unfixed as any who walk the surface.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: What does this 'intellectually stimulating' upbringing look like?
Havkelaag: In the literal sense, I will need to induce the egg to hatch via the application of certain currents to the creature inside.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: You would teach the child virtue, but rear it without patience. Curious.
Havkelaag: Tell me, then, philosopher - if patience delays the fostering of the other virtues, can it be rightly called virtuous?
Player: Patience does not delay, it simply tempers virtue. Curtails it from excess.
Havkelaag: A cautious, hesitant instinct. One I am afraid we do not have time for.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: Sounds pointless. Public opinion will hardly be swayed by such a small experiment.
Havkelaag: Not at first. But if the experiment proves successful, it must be repeated. Only then will we know if the findings are to be trusted.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: This experiment is barbaric. You're never getting the egg.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: You will stop this sick spectacle at once.
Malus Thorm: Sick. Quite. But on the cusp of a cure:
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Astarion: He's just like Cazador - utterly insane.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes you. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Their blades are uneven. Efficient surgery will require further training.
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Sparring is vital to progress. Have them practice on each other.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?
Malus Thorm: The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey.
Malus Thorm: Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart.
Malus Thorm: You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure.
Malus Thorm: Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: I sought purpose in the natural world - I see now that Shar is the only path. Show me how - I beg of you.
Player: I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
: True
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.
Player: May Shar guide your blessing hands.
Malus Thorm: And the rough vessels that are yours.
Malus Thorm: Tell me, what is the guiding principle of the goddess?
Player: Loss.
Malus Thorm: I profess there is another more profound.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Karlach: What the fuck is this loon talking about.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes you. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Your subject is tainted. Shar's succour must only be granted to the willing.
Malus Thorm: Hmmm. 'Only the willing may know the Lady's embrace.' You know her teachings well.
Malus Thorm: And yet, these sisters must exercise their gifts, for the art of absence lies in its execution.
Malus Thorm: How to proceed, I wonder.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?
Malus Thorm: The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey.
Malus Thorm: Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart.
Malus Thorm: You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure.
Malus Thorm: Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: My magic has blinded me - I see now that Shar is the only path. Show me how - I beg of you.
Player: I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
: True
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be.

Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.
Halsin: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic.
Halsin: Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: Glad I could be of help.
Halsin: I must admit, I didn't expect anyone would come to my aid. Who in their right mind would infiltrate a goblin infested temple. Unless...
Halsin: ...Hrrm. That look in your eyes - I've seen it before. Are you feeling all right?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows what’s inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn.
Halsin: But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do...
Halsin: How is this possible...?
Player: I don't know.
Halsin: You weren't speaking lightly when you said you needed help. Let me tell you what I know.
Halsin: I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them.
Halsin: Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected.
Halsin: I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help.
Halsin: I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from.
Halsin: That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: So all of this was for nothing.
Halsin: Patience. I can't just snap my fingers... but I know where the solution almost certainly lies.
Halsin: I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers.
Halsin: Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic.
Halsin: If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: You seem to know a lot about this. Will you come with me to Moonrise?
Halsin: I wish I could, but there's still work I've yet to finish - blood I've yet to spill.
Halsin: I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise.
Halsin: I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: Kagha was swayed by Shadow Druids. She nearly sealed the grove.
Halsin: Kagha... I should have suspected she'd take things too far. I'll deal with her when I can.
Halsin: But there are other matters to attend to before that.
Halsin: Chaos is welcome, in doses; it helps keep balance. But this is too much - this is unnatural.
Halsin: Help me kill the leaders of this horde, save my grove. Then I will help you.

Halsin: Three deaths could win us peace: the drow Minthara, the hobgoblin Dror Ragzlin, and that perversion of a priestess, Gut.
Halsin: They are the ones holding these parasites together. Remove them and nature will cure itself.
Player: You are aware you're asking me to kill a drow?
Halsin: You drow relish turning on your own, if there's something to be gained. Don't pretend otherwise.
Player: Not all drow are as you say.
Halsin: Unfair of me, perhaps, but I've had few encounters with drow to make me think otherwise.
Halsin: Perhaps you can enlighten me.
Player: I'll deal with this. You get to safety.
Halsin: I told you, nowhere is safe. Not while this rot festers. Once it is cut out - once the grove is secure - then I shall leave.
Player: Follow me, then. Your bear form may prove useful.
Halsin: Be warned - my presence could make things more difficult... I can only restrain my bear form so much. I won't be able to help but attack goblins.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player reaches for Shadowhear and shakes her shoulder (no contact needs to be shown). She wakes suddenly and gets to her feet, putting the artefact away.
Shadowheart: You... you knocked me out cold. I ought to return the favour - with interest.
Narrator: *She almost looks like she's weighing up whether to continue hostilities... until she notices the surrounds.*
Shadowheart: Wait. Where the hells are we? How are we alive?
NodeContext: Breaks off angry accusartion of player as she notices the surrounds.
Shadowheart: And speaking of - how are we alive...?
Player: Doesn't matter - we made it.
Shadowheart: True. Seems like we're the lucky ones, judging by all the corpses strewn about.
Shadowheart: I remember the ship, I remember falling... then nothing.
Player: What happened to our gith friend?
Shadowheart: You might want to reconsider calling her a friend - looks like she ran off without us.
Player: Now what?
Shadowheart: First things first - we need supplies, shelter, and most of all, a healer.
Shadowheart: We might have escaped, but we still have these little monsters in our heads.
Player: Do you have any idea where we are?
Player: What happened to our gith friend?
Player: Do you have any idea where we are?
Player: I'd better get moving. Farewell.
Shadowheart: We need each other, and we both know what's at stake. I can't think of better company.
Player: No. This is where we part ways.
Shadowheart: You sure about that? Neither of us knows what lies ahead.
Player: All right, fine. Let's stay together.
Shadowheart: One thing, just before we go. I wanted to thank you again, for freeing me.
Shadowheart: It would've been all too easy for you to run right past my pod, but you didn't. I'll remember that.
NodeContext: Genuine.

Fezzerk: Look what we got here - another little birdie wantin' to fly!
NodeContext: Cruel bravado.The goblin sees the player approach and boldly announces it to his cronies - he thinks some fresh victims have just turned up.
Fezzerk: Yehehueh! Flap those wings some more, an' I'll feed you a worm!
NodeContext: Greatly amused. A schoolyard bully tormenting the little kid. Projecting his voice a little (Fezzerk calls out to taunt his deep gnome prisoner, who rotates on the sail of a windmill a short-moderate distance off.)
'Yehehueh!' = Fezzerk's distinct laugh (a raspy, mean-spirited slur of a laugh)
Fezzerk: An' you - hope you got a stomach fer heights!
NodeContext: Confident, unpleasant. Turning his attention to the player to deliver a threat.
Player: I won't interfere. I just want to pass by.
Fezzerk: Heh, funny. That's what our birdie wanted.
NodeContext: Mocking.
Barcus Wroot: ...Release me this instant, you beasts!
NodeContext: Panicked, angry. Issuing an ultimatum even though he has no means of following through on it.
Fezzerk: 'Less you wanna join him up there, you'd best pay the toll.
NodeContext: Confident, threatening. Thinks he holds all the cards in a one-sided negotiation.
Fezzerk: Cough it up! ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
NodeContext: Fezzerk declares his price. (A ridiculously high sum - questionable whether he truly knows how absurd a demand this is)
Narrator: *The mark glows, but you feel nothing in response. Your illithid power is beyond reach until you rest.*
Player: That's a ridiculous amount. I'll make you a realistic offer. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_4_5dac5eea-faeb-459c-b675-46c51519b784])
Player: I might be willing to part with a more reasonable sum. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_5_8860ed48-ba5f-4b7b-82bf-f1220f967d41])
: True
Fezzerk: You wanna haggle? Fine. The price has just doubled!
Fezzerk: How do you like that? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_2_463b0f43-5410-412d-aba3-875cf81c38ca])
Player: I've changed my mind - release the gnome and clear off. Or else.
Fezzerk: Or else what, you'll fight us? Bit late to find some backbone, don't you reckon?
Fezzerk: You want this little cave-lurkin' wotsit?
Fezzerk: Find your own! He's ours an' we ain't sharin'!
Fezzerk: Find your own! He's ours!
Narrator: *A strange symbol glows, marked on their flesh, and something within you stirs in response.*
Player: I am a True Soul. Now, once again - release the gnome.
Fezzerk: I... yes. Whatever you want.
Narrator: *Something stirs deep within you, hungry and alert... it's taking something you'll never get back.*
Narrator: *The goblin's nostrils flare nervously. All of his bluster seems to vanish.*
Fezzerk: We're leaving.
Goblin Devout: What about the gnome? Ain't we s'posed to bring him to -
Fezzerk: I said we're leaving!
Fezzerk: Apologies, your grace. We didn't mean to doubt a True Soul. We'll be off.

Shadowheart: I thought I'd seen the last of you.
Shadowheart: Start another fight, and I'll finish it.
Player: Take it easy. I'm not looking to fight you again.
Shadowheart: Then what are you looking for? Because it seems like you're following me.
Shadowheart: If I wanted a tail, I'd kill a cat.

Player: I have more important things to do than follow you - surviving, for one.
Shadowheart: Fair point. Survival is the crux of it, for now.
Shadowheart: I suppose you came here for the same reason I did...
Player: Oh yes? Maybe you suppose too much.
Shadowheart: I don't think so. You need a healer, same as I do.
Shadowheart: But we'll have no such luck in this place, from what I've learned of it.
Shadowheart: I need to find a healer. As do you.
Player: We should join forces. Better odds of survival.
Shadowheart: I might've considered it... but your choice of company so far leaves a great deal to be desired.
Shadowheart: Get rid of the gith. Then we can talk about helping each other.
Lae'zel: I offer you cleansing. You'd cast it aside for this shka'keth?
Player: Why accept the company of one gith but not another?
Shadowheart: You helped me - I think I can trust you. But her? She's trouble.
Shadowheart: For your sake, you ought to nip this in the bud before she turns on you.
Player: If you trust me, then trust my judgement. We can help each other - all of us.
Shadowheart: All right, I'll come with you. I suspect you'll need someone watching your back.
Shadowheart: Call me Shadowheart.
Player: Time we got moving.
Player: I'm [GEN_PlayerName_c11eee1e-7815-6143-7233-f2427799fa53]. Time we got moving.
Shadowheart: Before we go, I wanted to thank you, for freeing me aboard the nautiloid.
Shadowheart: It would've been all too easy for you to run right past my pod, but you didn't. I'll remember that.

Kith'rak Voss: Now, now, child - your pet means to speak. Tell me, pet: why shouldn't I run you through this instant?

Fezzerk: Look what we got here - another little birdie wantin' to fly!
NodeContext: Cruel bravado.The goblin sees the player approach and boldly announces it to his cronies - he thinks some fresh victims have just turned up.

NodeContext: Greatly amused. A schoolyard bully. Projecting his voice a little (Fezzerk calls out to taunt his deep gnome prisoner, who rotates on the sail of a windmill a short-moderate distance off.)
'Yehehueh!' = Fezzerk's distinct laugh (a raspy, mean-spirited slur of a laugh)
Fezzerk: An' you - hope you got a stomach fer heights!
NodeContext: Confident, unpleasant. Turning his attention to the player to deliver a threat.
Player: I'm not looking for trouble - just want to pass by.
Fezzerk: Heh, funny. That's what our birdie wanted.
Barcus Wroot: ...Release me this instant, you beasts!
NodeContext: Panicked, angry. Issuing an ultimatum even though he has no means of following through on it.
Fezzerk: 'Less you wanna join him up there, you'd best pay the toll.
NodeContext: Confident, threatening. Thinks he holds all the cards in a one-sided negotiation.

NodeContext: Fezzerk declares his price. (A ridiculously high sum - questionable whether he truly knows how absurd a demand this is)

: True

Player: I've changed my mind - release the gnome and clear off. Or else.

Fezzerk: You want this little cave-lurkin' wotsit?
Fezzerk: Find your own! He's ours an' we ain't sharin'!
Fezzerk: Find your own! He's ours!
Narrator: *A strange symbol glows, marked on their flesh, and something within you stirs in response.*
Player: You will release the gnome. That's an order.
: True
Fezzerk: I... yes. Whatever you want.
Narrator: *A shadow swims across your vision, and a familiar voice tells you to be calm. You are loved.*
Narrator: *The goblin's nostrils flare nervously. All of his bluster seems to vanish.*
Fezzerk: We're leaving.

Fezzerk: I said we're leaving!
Fezzerk: There's plenty of sport an' rich pickings out there fer us. Move it!

: True

Shadowheart: Please. Don't make me do this - not after all we've been through.

Shadowheart: A beautiful night. Not even a hint of moon to sully Lady Shar's dark sky.

Shadowheart: Not fatalistic - pragmatic. We should do everything we can to tilt the odds in our favour. That's what I wanted to talk to you about.
Shadowheart: We should make an offering to Lady Shar, to seek her blessing and protection against what lies ahead. A Nightfall ritual.
Player: A Nightfall ritual - an act of wickedness and decadence in Lady Shar's name?
Shadowheart: Precisely. Care to show your devotion? Just say the word.
Shadowheart: Help me do this. You will not regret it.

Shadowheart: Wait until the others are asleep, then come with me. It might just save your life...
